subAssessmentDescription: A heap-based buffer overflow vulnerability has been discovered in libwebp versions before 1.0.1. The vulnerability is caused by an invalid check for buffer size in the WebPDecodeRGBInto function, which can be exploited by a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code or cause a denial of service. Red Hat's versions of the software are not affected by this vulnerability. Another vulnerability, CVE-2020-36329, has also been identified in libwebp, which is a use-after-free issue due to a prematurely killed thread. This vulnerability can also lead to data confidentiality and integrity risks. Additionally, a third vulnerability, CVE-2018-25011, has been found in libwebp, which is a heap-based buffer overflow in the PutLE16 function. All these vulnerabilities pose risks to data confidentiality, integrity, and system availability. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A use-after-free vulnerability was found in libwebp before version 1.0.1. This flaw occurs when a thread is terminated prematurely, leading to a use-after-free condition. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to compromise data confidentiality and integrity, as well as cause a denial of service. Another vulnerability in libwebp versions before 1.0.1 is a heap-based buffer overflow in the WebPDecodeRGBInto function, which can be triggered by an invalid buffer size check. This vulnerability also poses a risk to data confidentiality and integrity, as well as system availability. Additionally, a heap-based buffer overflow was discovered in the PutLE16 function of libwebp, identified as CVE-2018-25011. The impact of this vulnerability is similar to the previous ones. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected by CVE-2020-36329. Package updates are available to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a stack overflow flaw in the TIPC protocol functionality, a buffer overflow in the Transparent Inter Process Communication (TIPC) module, a privilege escalation vulnerability in the cgroups implementation, denial of service vulnerabilities in the Xen subsystem and the Xen network backend driver, a memory exposure vulnerability in the simulated networking device driver, a denial of service vulnerability in the Marvell WiFi-Ex USB device driver, a use-after-free vulnerability in the ARM Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) subsystem, a denial of service vulnerability in the Phone Network protocol (PhoNet) implementation, and a denial of service vulnerability in the Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS) protocol implementation. These vulnerabilities could allow remote attackers to crash the system, escalate privileges, or cause denial of service conditions. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities related to the Linux kernel's handling of NFS filesystems, UDF file system functionality, GPU i915 kernel driver functionality, branch predictor sharing in Intel processors, control groups and namespaces subsystem, and hanging of mounts in the NFS4 subsystem. These vulnerabilities could lead to data leaks, privilege escalation, denial of service, or information disclosure. It is recommended to upgrade to the specified package versions to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

The Linux kernel also includes a software mitigation for CVE-2022-24448 related to NFS filesystems. It is recommended to follow the provided update instructions for each specific vulnerability. subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability in json-schema versions before 0.4.0 allows for the improper modification of object prototype attributes, also known as 'Prototype Pollution'. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by sending a specially crafted request, potentially leading to the execution of arbitrary code on the system. This vulnerability affects the Oracle Communications Unified Assurance product, specifically the REST API component. Versions prior to 5.5.7.0.0 and 6.0.0.0.0 are affected. subAssessmentDescription: Python 3.x through 3.9.1 is vulnerable to a buffer overflow in PyCArg_repr in _ctypes/callproc.c, which may lead to remote code execution in certain Python applications that accept floating-point numbers as untrusted input. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by sending a specially-crafted argument to c_double.from_param, causing a buffer overflow and potentially executing arbitrary code on the system. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected by this vulnerability. There is a known exploit for this vulnerability. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
additionalData: {"cveDescriptionAdditionalInformation":"CVE-2021-3177 is a stack-based buffer overflow vulnerability in the ctypes module provided within Python. Applications that use ctypes without carefully validating the input passed to it may be vulnerable to this flaw, which would allow an attacker to overflow a buffer on the stack and crash the application. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability. Patched versions of the affected packages are available. subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in Expat (aka libexpat) and Oracle Outside In Technology. These vulnerabilities could allow remote attackers to execute arbitrary code, cause denial of service, or compromise the affected systems. The vulnerabilities include an integer overflow in the storeRawNames() function of Expat, which can be exploited to execute arbitrary code or cause a denial of service. In Oracle Outside In Technology, an unauthenticated attacker with network access via HTTPS can compromise the system, resulting in a takeover. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in Aruba products that allow attackers to potentially cause denial of service conditions or remote code execution using specially crafted XML input. subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability exists in the Apache Portable Runtime (APR) library, specifically in the apr_time_exp*() functions. When these functions are called with an invalid month field value, it can lead to out-of-bounds memory access, potentially revealing the contents of a different static heap value or causing program termination. This vulnerability can be exploited by an attacker to obtain sensitive information or launch a denial of service attack. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Mercurial prior to 4.3 is vulnerable to shell-injection attacks due to inadequate sanitization of hostnames passed to ssh. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary commands on the system. Additionally, Mercurial is also susceptible to a path traversal vulnerability, where an attacker can abuse a repository with a series of commits to trick Mercurial into writing outside of a given repository. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The GNU Multiple Precision Arithmetic Library (GMP) through version 6.2.1 is vulnerable to an integer overflow and resultant buffer overflow in the mpz/inp_raw.c file. This vulnerability can be exploited by an attacker sending specially crafted input, leading to a segmentation fault on 32-bit platforms. The impact of this vulnerability is a denial of service. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel, which could allow an attacker to gain elevated privileges, cause a denial of service, or execute arbitrary code. These vulnerabilities include a use-after-free flaw in aio_poll_complete_work of aio.c, a race condition in the poll implementation, a memory corruption in the BPF verifier, a cgroups access restriction issue, a Xen subsystem limitation, a Xen network backend driver limitation, a USB Gadget subsystem size restriction issue, a simulated networking device driver memory initialization issue, a cgroup process migration permission check issue, an aQuantia AQtion Ethernet device driver validation issue, an ARM Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) race condition, a Phone Network protocol reference counting issue, an eBPF verifier bounds checking issue, a Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS) memory deallocation issue, a BPF subsystem pointer tracking issue, a TIPC Protocol memory initialization issue, a Transparent Inter-Process Communication (TIPC) stack-based buffer overflow, a KVM memory operation restriction issue, and an ICMPv6 memory deallocation issue. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple issues that could allow an attacker to gain elevated privileges, read/write random pages of memory, and cause a denial of service. These vulnerabilities include improper handling of VM_IO|VM_PFNMAP vmas in KVM, enabling AVIC in nested guest VMs, insufficient processing time for cleanups of large SEV VMs, and use-after-free vulnerability in the KVM hypervisor implementation. Additionally, there is a flaw in the joystick device interface that could allow a local attacker to cause a denial of service or execute arbitrary code. Exploiting these vulnerabilities could result in local privilege escalation, exposure of sensitive information, or system crashes. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A race condition vulnerability exists in the Linux kernel SCTP sockets, allowing for kernel privilege escalation from the context of a network service or an unprivileged process. An attacker with network service privileges can exploit this vulnerability to escalate to root or from the context of an unprivileged user directly. Additionally, multiple use-after-free vulnerabilities have been discovered in the CAN BCM networking protocol, eBPF implementation, and WiFi implementation of the Linux kernel, which could lead to arbitrary code execution, denial of service, or exposure of sensitive information. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected by CVE-2021-23133. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux Kernel that could allow local attackers to elevate their privileges or execute arbitrary code. These vulnerabilities include a use-after-free flaw in the implementation of nfc sockets, a race condition in the CAN BCM networking protocol, improper enforcement of limits for pointer operations in the eBPF implementation, and various issues in the WiFi implementation that could lead to packet injection, decryption, or exposure of sensitive information. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in the SCTP implementation, Bluetooth subsystem, and f2fs module that could result in denial of service or arbitrary code execution. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple flaws that could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service (system crash), gain elevated privileges, or leak sensitive information. These vulnerabilities include writing beyond the end of an array, improper handling of error conditions, race conditions, memory deallocation issues, and buffer overflow. Exploiting these vulnerabilities could result in damage to data confidentiality, integrity, and system availability. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in the eBPF implementation, RPA PCI Hotplug driver, and Nosy driver that could lead to privilege escalation, information disclosure, and use-after-free. A local attacker with specific user privileges could exploit these vulnerabilities. Upgrading to the patched versions of the affected packages is recommended. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel and Xen hypervisor. These vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to cause a denial of service (system crash), execute arbitrary code, leak sensitive information, or exhaust memory. The vulnerabilities affect various components such as the Xen paravirtualization backend, DRM subsystem, Freescale Gianfar Ethernet driver, USB/IP driver, netfilter subsystem, video4linux subsystem, and the Nosy driver. Exploiting these vulnerabilities could result in zombie domains, host-wide denial of service, or memory exhaustion. Affected Linux versions include those with the fix for XSA-365 applied, versions back to at least 3.11, and specific package versions. Upgrading to the recommended package versions is advised to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple flaws that could allow a local attacker to crash the system, escalate privileges, or read/write portions of the host's physical memory. The vulnerabilities include an out-of-bounds memory write flaw in the joystick devices subsystem, a flaw in the KVM hypervisor implementation for AMD processors, and a use-after-free vulnerability in the KVM hypervisor implementation. An attacker could exploit these vulnerabilities to cause a denial of service, execute arbitrary code, or gain elevated privileges. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability exists in Cyrus SASL versions 2.1.17 through 2.1.27 before 2.1.28, where the plugins/sql.c file does not properly escape the password for a SQL INSERT or UPDATE statement. This vulnerability allows a remote authenticated attacker to execute arbitrary SQL commands, potentially leading to unauthorized access, modification, or deletion of information in the back-end database. The vulnerability is also present in various Oracle Communications Cloud Native Core products, including CNC Console, CNE, and SEPP, allowing a low privileged attacker with network access via HTTP to compromise these components and potentially take over the affected systems. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability in libssh2 versions before 1.9.0 allows for an integer overflow in the kex_method_diffie_hellman_group_exchange_sha256_key_exchange function in kex.c. This can result in an out-of-bounds read when packets are received from the server. An attacker who compromises an SSH server can exploit this vulnerability to disclose sensitive information or cause a denial of service on the client system when a user connects to the server. This issue is different from previous fixes and is not related to CVE-2019-3855. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability exists in the ion_buffer_kmap_get function of ion.c in the Android kernel. It is caused by a use-after-free issue resulting from an integer overflow. An attacker with local access to the system could exploit this vulnerability to escalate privileges without requiring additional execution privileges. No user interaction is necessary for exploitation. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A memory leak flaw in the Linux kernel's hugetlbfs memory usage was found in the way the user maps some regions of memory twice using shmget(). This vulnerability allows a local user to gain unauthorized access to data. Another vulnerability in the Linux kernel allows a local authenticated attacker to bypass security restrictions by exploiting flaws in mmap() and shmget(). There are also several other vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel, including a race condition in the timer implementation, a race condition in the overlay file system implementation, a use-after-free vulnerability in the NFC subsystem, and an integer overflow in the eBPF implementation. These vulnerabilities could lead to denial of service or arbitrary code execution. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected by CVE-2021-4002. Package updates are available to fix these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in libtiff, a library for handling TIFF images. These vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service, or trigger a crash in applications using libtiff. The vulnerabilities include an integer overflow flaw in the tif_getimage.c file, a buffer overflow vulnerability in tif_unix.c, a heap buffer overflow flaw in the cpContigBufToSeparateBuf() function of the tiffcp.c file, a floating-point exception flaw in the computeOutputPixelOffsets() function in tiffcrop.c, a NULL pointer dereference flaw, a reachable assertion failure in the JBIG functionality, and a heap-based buffer overflow flaw in the TIFF2PDF tool. The highest threat from these vulnerabilities is to confidentiality, integrity, and system availability. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: libtiff is vulnerable to multiple buffer overflow and denial of service vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities can be exploited by an attacker with a specially crafted TIFF file to execute arbitrary code, crash the application, or cause a denial of service. The vulnerabilities include a heap-based buffer overflow in the handling of TIFF images in libtiff's TIFF2PDF tool (CVE-2020-35524), an integer overflow in the tif_getimage.c file (CVE-2020-35523), a memory malloc failure in tif_pixarlog.c (CVE-2020-35522), and a memory allocation failure in tif_read.c (CVE-2020-35521). Other vulnerabilities include a buffer overflow in the memcpy function in tif_unix.c (CVE-2022-22844), a heap buffer overflow in the cpContigBufToSeparateBuf() function of the tiffcp.c file (CVE-2022-0924), a floating-point exception in the computeOutputPixelOffsets() function in tiffcrop.c (CVE-2022-0909), a NULL pointer dereference in the memcpy() function within the TIFFFetchNormalTag() in tif_dirread.c (CVE-2022-0908), a NULL pointer dereference in libtiff (CVE-2022-0907), and a reachable assertion failure in libtiff's JBIG functionality (CVE-2022-0865). [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a read-after-free memory flaw in the garbage collection for Unix domain socket file handlers, a double-free vulnerability in the Packet network protocol implementation, a race condition in the Unix domain socket implementation, a calculation error in the XFS file system, and various other flaws. These vulnerabilities could allow a local attacker to crash the system, escalate privileges, execute arbitrary code, or leak sensitive information. Specific package updates are available to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel before version 5.17.1 is vulnerable to multiple security issues. These include a refcount leak bug in net/llc/af_llc.c, a denial of service vulnerability caused by a refcount leak bug in llc_ui_bind() from /net/llc/af_llc.c, improper access restriction to the kernel debugger in secure boot environments, a use-after-free vulnerability in the netfilter subsystem, a denial of service vulnerability in the SCTP protocol implementation, a denial of service vulnerability in the btrfs file system implementation, uninitialized memory disclosure in the netfilter subsystem, a race condition in the virtual graphics memory manager, reference counting issue in the 802.2 LLC type 2 driver, and a double-free vulnerability in the EMS CAN/USB interface implementation. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a use-after-free flaw in the FUSE filesystem, a privilege escalation flaw in the FUSE filesystem, a bypass of UEFI Secure Boot restrictions, a use-after-free vulnerability in the netfilter subsystem, a denial of service vulnerability in the SCTP protocol implementation, a privilege escalation flaw in the cgroup process migration implementation, a use-after-free vulnerability in the FUSE file system, a vulnerability in the KVM implementation, a use-after-free vulnerability in the 6pack protocol implementation, a vulnerability in the PF_KEYv2 implementation, a denial of service vulnerability in the X.25 network protocols implementation, a vulnerability in the Xen para-virtualization device frontends, a use-after-free vulnerability in the USB Gadget file system interface, a vulnerability in the USB SR9700 ethernet device driver, a reference counting flaw in the 802.2 LLC type 2 driver, a double-free vulnerability in the Microchip CAN BUS Analyzer interface implementation, and a double-free vulnerability in the EMS CAN/USB interface implementation. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple Linux PV device frontends are vulnerable to attacks by backends due to race conditions in the grant table interfaces. This can result in potential data leaks, data corruption, and denial of service. The affected frontends include blkfront, netfront, scsifront, and the gntalloc driver. The xenbus driver also has a similar problem. Additionally, several Xen para-virtualization device frontends do not properly restrict the access rights of device backends, allowing an attacker to gain access to memory pages of a guest VM or cause a denial of service. Other vulnerabilities include failure to check the success of removing the granted access of a shared ring buffer, use-after-free vulnerabilities, and improper handling of certain error conditions in various drivers and protocols. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel before version 5.14.12 is vulnerable to multiple security issues. One of the vulnerabilities, identified as CVE-2021-41864, allows unprivileged users to trigger an eBPF multiplication integer overflow in the prealloc_elems_and_freelist function in kernel/bpf/stackmap.c, resulting in an out-of-bounds write. This could lead to a system crash or a leak of internal kernel information. Another vulnerability, CVE-2021-38300, involves a flaw in the cBPF JIT compiler that may produce machine code with incorrect branches, allowing an unprivileged user to execute arbitrary kernel code. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities such as CVE-2021-3764 and CVE-2021-3744, which involve memory leaks in the ccp-ops crypto driver, and CVE-2021-37159, which is a use-after-free vulnerability in the USB High Speed Mobile Devices functionality. Another race condition vulnerability, CVE-2021-20321, exists in the OverlayFS subsystem, allowing a local user to crash the system. Lastly, CVE-2021-20317 involves a race condition in the timer implementation, which can be exploited by a privileged attacker to cause a denial of service. Red Hat's versions of the associated software have been determined to NOT be affected by CVE-2021-41864. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel before version 5.13.13 has multiple vulnerabilities that could allow an attacker to gain elevated privileges, execute arbitrary code, expose sensitive information, or cause a denial of service. These vulnerabilities include a slab out-of-bounds write in the decode_data function in drivers/net/hamradio/6pack.c, a race condition in the Atheros Ath9k WiFi driver, improper access permission computation in the KVM hypervisor implementation, a race condition in the ext4 file system when writing xattrs to an inode, and improper validation checks in the 6pack network protocol driver. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: There is a vulnerability in libxml2's xmllint in versions before 2.9.11, which could be exploited by an attacker who submits a crafted file to trigger a use-after-free. This flaw has the potential to impact confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Another vulnerability in libxml2 allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the system by exploiting a use-after-free in xmlEncodeEntitiesInternal() in entities.c. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected by this vulnerability. Additionally, there are several other vulnerabilities in libxml2 that could lead to denial of service attacks or the execution of arbitrary code. These vulnerabilities affect specific versions of Ubuntu and Amazon Linux 2. Upgrading to version 2.9.12 of libxml2 is recommended to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: There is a vulnerability in the xml entity encoding functionality of libxml2 in versions before 2.9.11. An attacker who can provide a crafted file to an application linked with the affected functionality of libxml2 could trigger an out-of-bounds read. This flaw could lead to application availability issues, with potential impacts to confidentiality and integrity if an attacker can exploit memory information. The vulnerability has been observed in Nokogiri, GNOME libxml2, Oracle Java SE, and Ubuntu. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected. The vulnerability can be mitigated by upgrading to libxml2 version 2.9.11 or higher. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: There is a vulnerability in libxml2 versions before 2.9.11 that allows an attacker to trigger a use-after-free flaw by submitting a crafted file to an application linked with libxml2. This vulnerability can lead to a compromise of confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Another vulnerability in libxml2's xmllint allows an attacker to trigger a use-after-free flaw by submitting a crafted file to xmllint. The impact of this vulnerability is also to confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in Oracle Enterprise Manager Base Platform and Oracle PeopleSoft Enterprise PeopleTools that allow unauthenticated attackers with network access to compromise the respective platforms, potentially resulting in a takeover. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected by these vulnerabilities. Furthermore, there are several vulnerabilities in libxml2 that can cause denial of service or possible execution of arbitrary code. These vulnerabilities affect specific versions of Ubuntu and have been addressed with updates. Apple TV devices are also affected by a vulnerability in libxml2 that allows arbitrary code execution. Amazon Linux 2 is affected by vulnerabilities in libxml2 that can cause a NULL pointer dereference and a use-after-free. Upgrading to libxml2 version 2.9.12 resolves these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability found in libxml2 versions before 2.9.11 allows for a NULL dereference when parsing XML mixed content, leading to a denial of service. This flaw can be exploited by an attacker to crash the application by parsing an untrusted XML document in recovery mode and post-validation. The vulnerability affects GNOME libxml2, Oracle HTTP Server, and various Ubuntu versions. It can result in system availability issues and potential exposure of sensitive information. Additionally, there are other related vulnerabilities such as use-after-free flaws in libxml2 and xmllint, which can also lead to denial of service and impact confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Upgrading to version 2.9.12 of libxml2 resolves these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple security flaws. The BPF JIT compilers in the kernel have incorrect computation of branch displacements, allowing arbitrary code execution within the kernel context. This vulnerability can be exploited by a local authenticated attacker to gain elevated privileges and execute arbitrary code. Another vulnerability in the overlayfs implementation allows a local attacker to gain elevated privileges. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected by one of the vulnerabilities. Additionally, there are several other vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel, including a use-after-free vulnerability in the Nosy driver, an information disclosure vulnerability due to uninitialized data structure, a denial-of-service vulnerability in the usbip driver, a local privilege escalation vulnerability due to incorrect BPF JIT branch displacement computation, a buffer overflow vulnerability in the RPA PCI Hotplug driver, a race condition vulnerability in the btrfs file-system, a buffer overflow vulnerability in the rtw_wx_set_scan driver, an out-of-bounds write vulnerability in setsockopt IPT_SO_SET_REPLACE, an integer underflow vulnerability in the eBPF verification code, memory leaks in various kernel functions, and a bypass for Spectre v1 hardening in the eBPF engine. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel before version 5.14.15 is vulnerable to an array-index-out-of-bounds flaw in the detach_capi_ctr function in drivers/isdn/capi/kcapi.c. This flaw could allow a local attacker to execute arbitrary code or cause a denial of service condition on the system. Additionally, there are several other vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel, including a race condition in the timer implementation, a race condition in the overlay file system implementation, a use-after-free vulnerability in the NFC subsystem, and an integer overflow in the eBPF implementation. These vulnerabilities could lead to data leakage, system crashes, denial of service, or arbitrary code execution. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability exists in qs before version 6.10.3, which is used in Express before version 4.17.3 and other products. It allows attackers to cause a Node process hang for an Express application by exploiting the __proto__ key. In many typical Express use cases, an unauthenticated remote attacker can place the attack payload in the query string of the URL used to visit the application. The fix for this vulnerability was backported to qs versions 6.9.7, 6.8.3, 6.7.3, 6.6.1, 6.5.3, 6.4.1, 6.3.3, and 6.2.4, making Express version 4.17.3 (which includes the fix) not vulnerable. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel through version 5.17.1 has a double-free vulnerability in the ems_usb_start_xmit function in drivers/net/can/usb/ems_usb.c. This vulnerability allows a local attacker to execute arbitrary code on the system by sending a specially-crafted request. Additionally, there are several other vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel, including a use-after-free vulnerability, a NULL pointer dereference, and a race condition, which could lead to privilege escalation, denial of service, or information leaks. subAssessmentDescription: A vulnerability was found in the Linux kernel's cgroup_release_agent_write in the kernel/cgroup/cgroup-v1.c function. This flaw, under certain circumstances, allows the use of the cgroups v1 release_agent feature to escalate privileges and bypass the namespace isolation unexpectedly. Another vulnerability in the Oracle Communications Diameter Signaling Router product allows a low privileged attacker to compromise the system and take over the router. Multiple vulnerabilities have also been discovered in the Linux kernel, including a privilege escalation vulnerability, denial of service vulnerabilities, memory leaks, and buffer overflow vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities could allow attackers to gain elevated privileges, cause denial of service, expose sensitive information, or execute arbitrary code. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple race condition and use-after-free vulnerabilities in various subsystems, including Bluetooth, CAN BCM networking protocol, eBPF implementation, and WiFi implementation. These vulnerabilities could allow a local attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service, or escalate privileges on the system. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in the f2fs module, ACPI, NFS, HID, netfilter, and other components. Exploiting these vulnerabilities could result in memory corruption, information disclosure, data integrity and confidentiality issues, and system crashes. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected by some of these vulnerabilities. Patched versions of the affected packages are available for remediation. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel before version 5.11.14 has multiple vulnerabilities that could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service, or leak sensitive information. These vulnerabilities include a use-after-free flaw in the cipso_v4_genopt function, a reference counting error in the NFC LLCP protocol implementation, a buffer overflow in the RPA PCI Hotplug driver, and a race condition in the btrfs file system implementation, among others. Exploiting these vulnerabilities could lead to system crashes, memory exhaustion, or the execution of arbitrary code. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel. One of the vulnerabilities is a use-after-free flaw in the DCCP CCID structure, which could allow a local attacker to execute arbitrary code or cause a denial of service condition. Another vulnerability is a race condition in the hugetlb sysctl implementation, which could result in a system crash. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in the ext4 file system implementation, XFS file system implementation, overlay file system, and block layer subsystem that could lead to denial of service or bypass of intended restrictions. These vulnerabilities have been fixed in various versions of the Linux kernel. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in different software components. The first vulnerability is found in the Linux kernel versions 3.16 through 5.13.x before 5.13.4, which allows an unprivileged user to escalate privileges to root by exploiting an integer overflow and out-of-bounds write in fs/seq_file.c. The second vulnerability affects the Oracle Communications Session Border Controller product versions 8.2, 8.3, 8.4, and 9.0, allowing a low privileged attacker to compromise the system and take over the controller. The third vulnerability is an out-of-bounds write flaw in the Linux kernel's seq_file in the Filesystem layer, affecting Amazon Linux 2. This flaw allows a local attacker with user privileges to access out-of-bound memory, potentially leading to a system crash or information leak. Lastly, a vulnerability identified as CVE-2021-33909 affects the kernel package version 5.10.168.1-1, allowing an attacker to exploit a size_t-to-int conversion vulnerability in the filesystem layer. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple security issues, including buffer overflows, use-after-free, and insufficient memory initialization. These vulnerabilities could allow a local attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service, or expose sensitive information. Specifically, the st21nfca_connectivity_event_received function in drivers/nfc/st21nfca/se.c is susceptible to buffer overflows due to untrusted length parameters. The nouveau graphics driver is affected by a use-after-free vulnerability during device removal. The Spectre Variant 2 mitigations for AMD processors on Linux are insufficient in some situations, potentially exposing sensitive information. The netfilter subsystem and the MMC/SD subsystem have memory initialization issues that could lead to the exposure of sensitive information. The USB gadget subsystem and the Remote NDIS (RNDIS) USB gadget implementation have validation vulnerabilities that could cause a denial of service or expose kernel memory. The ST21NFCA NFC driver and the Xilinx USB2 device gadget driver have size validation issues that could result in a denial of service or arbitrary code execution. A local attacker with normal user privileges could exploit these vulnerabilities. A security update is available to address these issues. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A flaw was found in the KVM's AMD code for supporting SVM nested virtualization. The flaw occurs when processing the VMCB (virtual machine control block) provided by the L1 guest to spawn/handle a nested guest (L2). Due to improper validation of the "int_ctl" field, this issue could allow a malicious L1 to enable AVIC support (Advanced Virtual Interrupt Controller) for the L2 guest. As a result, the L2 guest would be allowed to read/write physical pages of the host, resulting in a crash of the entire system, leak of sensitive data or potential guest-to-host escape. This vulnerability affects Linux kernel versions prior to 5.14-rc7. Another vulnerability, CVE-2021-3656, also affects the KVM hypervisor implementation for AMD processors in the Linux kernel. This vulnerability allows a malicious L1 guest to disable VMLOAD/VMSAVE intercepts and VLS (Virtual VMLOAD/VMSAVE) for the L2 guest, enabling the L2 guest to read/write physical pages of the host. The impact of this vulnerability is a crash of the entire system, leakage of sensitive data, or potential guest-to-host escape. The Linux kernel is also vulnerable to a denial of service caused by improper input validation of the "int_ctl" VMCB field. This vulnerability can be exploited by a local authenticated attacker to crash the system or obtain sensitive information from the physical memory. Additionally, there are other vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel, including a race condition in the ext4 subsystem, a flaw in the computation of access permissions of a shadow page, an out-of-bounds read flaw in VT, and a flaw in the OverlayFS subsystem that allows a local user to access hidden files. Security updates are available to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

These vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service, or escalate privileges on the system. Additionally, there is a vulnerability in the OverlayFS subsystem that could allow a local user to crash the system, and a race condition issue that could cause a denial of service. Package updates are available to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple security issues. One vulnerability, CVE-2021-3753, allows a local attacker to obtain sensitive information or cause a denial of service condition by exploiting an out-of-bounds read flaw in VT. Another vulnerability, CVE-2021-3732, allows a local user to access hidden files that should not be accessible by mounting the TmpFS filesystem with OverlayFS. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities related to the KVM's AMD code for supporting SVM nested virtualization, including CVE-2021-3656 and CVE-2021-3653, which could allow a malicious L1 guest to crash the system, leak sensitive data, or potentially escape to the host. The highest threat from these vulnerabilities is to data confidentiality, integrity, and system availability. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The npm package "tar" (aka node-tar) before versions 4.4.18, 5.0.10, and 6.1.9 has an arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution vulnerability. This vulnerability occurs on Windows systems when extracting tar files that contain a path with a different drive letter than the extraction target. The logic used to sanitize and resolve paths is insufficient, allowing an attacker to create or overwrite arbitrary files and execute arbitrary code on the system. This vulnerability only affects users of `node-tar` on Windows systems. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The npm package "tar" (aka node-tar) before versions 4.4.18, 5.0.10, and 6.1.9 has an arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution vulnerability. By creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink that resolves to the same entry in the filesystem, an attacker could use an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location and extract arbitrary files into that location, allowing for arbitrary file creation and overwrite. This issue was addressed in releases 4.4.18, 5.0.10, and 6.1.9. The v3 branch of node-tar has been deprecated and did not receive patches for these issues. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
additionalData: {"cveDescriptionAdditionalInformation":"The problem is addressed in the patched versions by normalizing unicode values, normalizing slashes on Windows systems, and clearing the directory cache when encountering a symbolic link on Windows systems. subAssessmentDescription: The npm package "tar" (aka node-tar) before versions 4.4.16, 5.0.8, and 6.1.7 has an arbitrary file creation/overwrite and arbitrary code execution vulnerability. By creating a directory and replacing it with a symlink, an attacker could use an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location and extract arbitrary files into that location, allowing for arbitrary file creation and overwrite. Additionally, on case-insensitive filesystems, a tar archive containing a directory and a symbolic link with the same name could lead to the creation of the symbolic link removing the directory from the filesystem but not from the internal directory cache, resulting in subsequent file entries being placed in the target of the symbolic link. These issues were addressed in releases 4.4.16, 5.0.8, and 6.1.7. The v3 branch of node-tar has been deprecated and did not receive patches for these issues. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
additionalData: {"cveDescriptionAdditionalInformation":"The problem is addressed by normalizing all paths to use \"/\" as a path separator and performing directory cache pruning case-insensitively. Note that this means that the `entry` objects exposed in various parts of tar's API will now always use \"/\" as a path separator, even on Windows systems. [Generated by subAssessmentDescription: The npm package "tar" (aka node-tar) before versions 6.1.1, 5.0.6, 4.4.14, and 3.3.2 has an arbitrary File Creation/Overwrite vulnerability due to insufficient absolute path sanitization. This allows an attacker to create or overwrite arbitrary files on the system by using a specially-crafted tar file containing "dot dot" sequences (/../). The vulnerability occurs when file paths contain repeated path roots, such as `////home/user/.bashrc`, where `node-tar` only strips a single path root. As a result, the resulting path (`///home/user/.bashrc`) still resolves to an absolute path, enabling the attacker to perform arbitrary file creation and overwrite. subAssessmentDescription: The npm package "tar" (aka node-tar) before versions 6.1.2, 5.0.7, 4.4.15, and 3.2.3 has an arbitrary File Creation/Overwrite vulnerability via insufficient symlink protection. By first creating a directory, and then replacing that directory with a symlink, it was possible to bypass `node-tar` symlink checks on directories, allowing an untrusted tar file to symlink into an arbitrary location and subsequently extract arbitrary files into that location, thus allowing arbitrary file creation and overwrite. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: An integer overflow vulnerability was discovered in GNOME GLib before version 2.66.6 and 2.67.x before 2.67.3. The issue occurs in the g_bytes_new function on 64-bit platforms due to an implicit cast from 64 bits to 32 bits, leading to potential memory corruption. This vulnerability could be exploited by a remote attacker to cause a denial of service by corrupting memory. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A logic issue in the CUPS component of Apple macOS Monterey and macOS Big Sur allows a local authenticated attacker to gain elevated privileges on the system. By using a specially-crafted application, an authenticated attacker could exploit this vulnerability to gain elevated privileges. Additionally, a remote attacker could compromise the affected system by exploiting an error in the implementation of the 'Local' authorization mechanism in CUPS, allowing them to authenticate as root/admin without the 32-byte secret key and execute arbitrary code on the system. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The avahi-daemon package in Debian versions prior to 0.8-1 is vulnerable to privilege escalation and denial of service attacks. The vulnerability is caused by improper privilege management in the code of the main shell script, allowing a local authenticated attacker to gain elevated privileges on the system. By utilizing a specially-crafted symlink, the attacker can exploit this vulnerability to create arbitrary files or update arbitrary files' timestamps. This vulnerability only affects the packaging for Debian GNU/Linux and not the upstream Avahi product. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Yarn, a package manager, is vulnerable to an untrusted search path flaw. This flaw allows an attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the system by tricking a victim into running certain Yarn commands in a directory with attacker-controlled content. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Upgrade to Debian Node-Yarnpkg version 1.22.19+~cs24.27.18-1 or later, to Yarnpkg Yarn version 1.22.13 or later or to Yarn Yarn version 1.22.13 or later. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The zlib library versions 1.2.11 and earlier are vulnerable to memory corruption when compressing data with many distant matches. This vulnerability can be exploited by a remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) by triggering memory corruption and crashing the application. The vulnerability has been identified in various products, including Oracle Communications Cloud Native Core Console, Oracle Communications Cloud Native Core Network Exposure Function, Oracle Communications Cloud Native Core Security Edge Protection Proxy, Oracle Communications Cloud Native Core Unified Data Repository, Oracle GoldenGate, MySQL Server, and PeopleSoft Enterprise PeopleTools. Additionally, the zlib library in Amazon Linux 2 and openjdk8 is also affected by this vulnerability. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: cURL libcurl versions 7.1.1 to 7.75.0 are vulnerable to an "Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor". This vulnerability occurs when libcurl fails to strip off user credentials from the URL when automatically populating the Referer: HTTP request header field in outgoing HTTP requests. As a result, sensitive data, including user credentials, can be leaked to the server that is the target of the second HTTP request. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability to obtain user credentials and launch further attacks against the affected system. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability in cURL libcurl versions 7.7 through 7.76.1 allows for information disclosure when the `-t` command line option, known as `CURLOPT_TELNETOPTIONS` in libcurl, is used to send variable=content pairs to TELNET servers. This flaw in the option parser for sending NEW_ENV variables can result in uninitialized data from a stack-based buffer being passed to the server, potentially revealing sensitive internal information to the server using a clear-text network protocol. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to obtain sensitive internal information and launch further attacks against the affected system. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Expat (aka libexpat) before version 2.4.3 is vulnerable to multiple integer overflow vulnerabilities, including storeAtts, nextScaffoldPart, lookup, defineAttribute, build_model, addBinding, and doProlog in xmlparse.c. These vulnerabilities could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the system or cause a crash by persuading a victim to open a specially-crafted file. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Expat (aka libexpat) before version 2.4.3 is vulnerable to an integer overflow in the doProlog function in xmlparse.c. This vulnerability can be exploited by a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the system by persuading a victim to open a specially-crafted file. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to availability, confidentiality, and integrity. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A flaw in the processing of received ICMP errors in the Linux kernel allows for the ability to quickly scan open UDP ports. This vulnerability enables an off-path remote user to bypass UDP source port randomization, potentially compromising confidentiality and integrity. Additionally, there are several other vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel, including a data leak flaw in XFS filesystem, a memory leak flaw in hugetlbfs memory usage, a flaw in the Linux SCTP stack, and denial of service flaws in the Xen hypervisor subsystem. These vulnerabilities could lead to unauthorized access, data leaks, and denial of service attacks. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A vulnerability in cURL libcurl versions 7.20.0 to 7.78.0 allows a remote attacker to bypass the requirement for a successful upgrade to TLS when communicating with an IMAP, POP3, or FTP server. By sending a specially crafted response, the attacker can force cURL to continue its operations without TLS encryption, exposing sensitive data in clear text over the network. Another vulnerability in cURL libcurl allows a remote attacker to inject responses and intercept communications before the STARTTLS process. Additionally, there is a vulnerability in cURL libcurl when sending data to an MQTT server, which could lead to a denial of service or arbitrary code execution. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: OpenSSL is vulnerable to a NULL pointer dereference in signature_algorithms processing, which can be exploited by sending a maliciously crafted renegotiation ClientHello message. This vulnerability can lead to a denial of service attack, causing the TLS server to crash. The affected versions are OpenSSL 1.1.1 (all versions) and MySQL Server 5.7.33 and prior, as well as 8.0.23 and prior. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected. The recommended remediation is to upgrade to OpenSSL 1.1.1k. For Ubuntu systems, the vulnerability can be fixed by updating to the following package versions: libcrypto1.1-udeb - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9, libssl-dev - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9, openssl - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9, libssl-doc - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9, libssl1.1-udeb - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9, libssl1.1 - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9. No workaround is provided. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Upgrade to OpenSSL 1.1.1k. For Ubuntu systems, update to the following package versions: libcrypto1.1-udeb - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9, libssl-dev - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9, openssl - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9, libssl-doc - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9, libssl1.1-udeb - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9, libssl1.1 - 1.1.1-1ubuntu2.1~18.04.9. For MySQL Server, upgrade to the latest version. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A vulnerability has been discovered in PostgreSQL versions before 13.3, 12.7, 11.12, 10.17, and 9.6.22. Authenticated database users can exploit this flaw by modifying certain SQL array values, allowing them to write arbitrary bytes to a wide area of server memory. subAssessmentDescription: The libjpeg-turbo library is vulnerable to multiple issues, including an integer overflow and subsequent heap corruption, as well as incorrect handling of certain BMP and JPEG images. These vulnerabilities could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the system or expose sensitive information. In particular, an attacker could exploit the integer overflow and heap corruption to execute arbitrary code by persuading a victim to open a specially-crafted file. The vulnerabilities affect various versions of Android and Ubuntu. A specific version upgrade is recommended to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in Linux PV device frontends, Xen, and the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities could allow attackers to gain unauthorized access to memory pages of a guest VM, cause data leaks or corruption, and trigger denial of service attacks. The vulnerabilities affect various components including blkfront, netfront, scsifront, gntalloc, xenbus, USB Gadget file system interface, USB gadget subsystem, Remote NDIS (RNDIS) USB gadget implementation, ST21NFCA NFC driver, USB SR9700 ethernet device driver, and Xilinx USB2 device gadget driver. Exploiting these vulnerabilities could result in exposure of sensitive information, system crashes, or execution of arbitrary code. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple Linux PV device frontends are vulnerable to attacks by backends due to race conditions in the grant table interfaces. This can result in potential data leaks, data corruption, and denial of service. The affected frontends include blkfront, netfront, scsifront, and the gntalloc driver. The xenbus driver also has a similar problem. Additionally, several frontends delay freeing a grant reference, allowing the backend to retain access to the memory page even after it has been freed and reused for a different purpose. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux Kernel, which could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service, or expose sensitive information. These vulnerabilities include a use-after-free flaw in the nfcmrvl_nci_unregister_dev() function, a race condition in the network packet scheduler implementation, a use-after-free vulnerability in the netfilter subsystem, a memory initialization issue in the block layer subsystem, race conditions in the Advanced Linux Sound Architecture (ALSA) framework, use-after-free vulnerabilities in the 6pack and mkiss protocols, a race condition in the floppy disk driver, use-after-free vulnerabilities in the Atheros ath9k wireless device driver and the perf subsystem, a memory cleanup issue in the Marvell NFC device driver, and race conditions in the NFC subsystem. An attacker with local access could exploit these vulnerabilities to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service, or expose sensitive information. [Generated by AI]

Exploiting these vulnerabilities could result in system crashes, privilege escalation, or unauthorized access to sensitive information. A security update is available to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple Linux PV device frontends are vulnerable to attacks by backends due to race conditions in the grant table interfaces. This can result in potential data leaks, data corruption, and denial of service. The affected frontends include blkfront, netfront, scsifront, and the gntalloc driver. The xenbus driver also has a similar problem. Additionally, several frontends delay freeing a grant reference, allowing the backend to retain access to the memory page even after it has been freed and reused for a different purpose. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple security flaws that could lead to denial of service (DoS) attacks, privilege escalation, information disclosure, and system crashes. These vulnerabilities include incorrect connection-setup ordering in the NFSv4 client, missed possible mispredicted branches in the BPF verifier, improper tracking of per-cpu ring buffer state in the tracing subsystem, improper validation of RTAS arguments in the KVM implementation for PowerPC systems, improper input length validation in the Virtio console implementation, and improper handling of device removal events in the MAX-3421 host USB device driver. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities related to the non-transparent sharing of branch predictor and an unprivileged write to the file handler in the control groups and namespaces subsystem. Exploiting these vulnerabilities could result in a variety of impacts, including system crashes, privilege escalation, information disclosure, and denial of service. Upgrading to the specified package versions is recommended to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A flaw was found in Nettle in versions before 3.7.2, where several Nettle signature verification functions (GOST DSA, EDDSA & ECDSA) result in the Elliptic Curve Cryptography point (ECC) multiply function being called with out-of-range scalers, possibly resulting in incorrect results. This flaw allows an attacker to force an invalid signature, causing an assertion failure or possible validation. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
additionalData: {"cveDescriptionAdditionalInformation":"The gnutls packages provide the GNU Transport Layer Security (GnuTLS) library, which implements cryptographic algorithms and protocols such as SSL, TLS, and DTLS. Nettle is a cryptographic library that is designed to fit easily in almost any context: In crypto toolkits for object-oriented languages, such as C++, Python, or Pike, in applications like LSH or GNUPG, or even in kernel space. subAssessmentDescription: A heap use-after-free vulnerability was found in systemd before version v245-rc1, where asynchronous Polkit queries are performed while handling dbus messages. This flaw can be abused by a local unprivileged attacker to crash systemd services or potentially execute code and elevate their privileges, by sending specially crafted dbus messages. Another vulnerability in systemd allows a local attacker to execute arbitrary code on the system or cause the system to crash by exploiting a heap use-after-free vulnerability in the bus_verify_polkit_async() function. Additionally, systemd incorrectly handles certain PIDFile files, which can be exploited by a local attacker to trick systemd into killing privileged processes. Another issue in systemd is the mishandling of certain udevadm trigger commands, which can be exploited by a local attacker to cause systemd to consume resources and lead to a denial of service. Furthermore, systemd incorrectly handles services that use the DynamicUser property, allowing a local attacker to access resources owned by a different service in the future. Lastly, systemd mishandles certain Polkit queries, which can be exploited by a local attacker to crash systemd, resulting in a denial of service, or possibly execute arbitrary code and escalate privileges. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Mercurial prior to version 4.3 is vulnerable to a missing symlink check that can allow malicious repositories to modify files outside the repository. Additionally, a shell command injection flaw related to the handling of 'ssh' URLs has been discovered in Mercurial, which can be exploited to execute shell commands with the privileges of the user running the Mercurial client. subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability exists in the way libcurl handles the STARTTLS negotiation process when connecting to an IMAP, POP3, SMTP, or FTP server to exchange data securely. When multiple responses are received before the TLS upgrade, curl caches these responses and continues to use and trust them even after upgrading to TLS. This flaw allows a Man-In-The-Middle attacker to inject fake responses and intercept communications, tricking curl into sending data back to the user as if it came from the TLS-protected server. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Mercurial before version 4.1.3 is vulnerable to an arbitrary code execution flaw. The vulnerability exists in the "hg serve --stdio" command, which allows remote authenticated users to launch the Python debugger and execute arbitrary code by using "--debugger" as a repository name. This flaw occurs due to improper validation of the repository name. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code on the system. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple race condition vulnerabilities, including ext4_write_inline_data_end in fs/ext4/inline.c, Atheros Ath9k WiFi driver, KVM hypervisor implementation, and ext4 file system. These vulnerabilities could lead to denial of service, exposure of sensitive information, privilege escalation, system crash, or execution of arbitrary code. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in OverlayFS subsystem and KVM's AMD code for supporting SVM nested virtualization. These vulnerabilities could allow a local attacker to gain access to hidden files, disable intercepts, read/write physical pages of the host, and potentially escape from the guest to the host. Security updates are available to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel. The first vulnerability, identified as CVE-2022-21499, allows a privileged attacker to bypass UEFI Secure Boot restrictions. The second vulnerability, identified as CVE-2022-1966, is a use-after-free vulnerability in the netfilter subsystem that can be exploited by a local attacker to cause a denial of service or execute arbitrary code. The third vulnerability, identified as CVE-2021-3772, is related to the SCTP protocol implementation and can be exploited by a remote attacker to cause a denial of service. The fourth vulnerability, identified as CVE-2021-4149, is a flaw in the btrfs file system implementation that can be exploited by a local attacker to cause a kernel deadlock. The fifth vulnerability, identified as CVE-2022-1016, is a memory initialization issue in the netfilter subsystem that can be exploited by a local attacker to expose sensitive information. The sixth vulnerability, identified as CVE-2022-1419, is a race condition in the virtual graphics memory manager that can lead to an information leak. The seventh vulnerability, identified as CVE-2022-28356, is a reference counting issue in the 802.2 LLC type 2 driver that can be exploited by a local attacker to cause a denial of service. The eighth vulnerability, identified as CVE-2022-28390, is a double-free vulnerability in the EMS CAN/USB interface implementation that can be exploited by a local attacker to cause a denial of service. The ninth vulnerability, identified as CVE-2022-21499, is a deadlock problem in the btrfs file system that can be exploited by a user with local privileges to cause a denial of service. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a data leak flaw in the XFS filesystem, a double-free vulnerability in the Packet network protocol implementation, a race condition in the Unix domain socket implementation, a size calculation issue in the XFS file system, a use-after-free vulnerability in the NFC Controller Interface, a validation issue in the aQuantia AQtion Ethernet device driver, a GPU TLB flush issue in the Intel i915 graphics driver, and a stale entry issue in the VMware Virtual GPU driver. These vulnerabilities could allow local attackers to leak sensitive information, cause denial of service, or possibly execute arbitrary code. A specific version to upgrade to is provided for the XFS filesystem vulnerability, while the other vulnerabilities require a generic upgrade. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel through version 5.15.8 has multiple vulnerabilities that could allow an attacker to gain sensitive information, escalate privileges, cause denial of service, or execute arbitrary code. These vulnerabilities include a refcount leak in pep_sock_accept, improper access restriction in cgroups v1 release_agent, inadequate limitation of events driver domains in the Xen subsystem, excessive queued packets in the Xen network backend driver, uninitialized memory in the simulated networking device driver, mishandling of error conditions in the Marvell WiFi-Ex USB device driver, a race condition leading to a use-after-free vulnerability in the ARM Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) subsystem, reference counting issues in the Phone Network protocol (PhoNet) implementation and the Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS) protocol implementation, and a stack-based buffer overflow in the Transparent Inter-Process Communication (TIPC) protocol implementation. These vulnerabilities could result in information disclosure, privilege escalation, denial of service, or system crashes. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: OpenJPEG is an open source library for reading and writing image files in JPEG2000 format. It is vulnerable to multiple flaws that could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service, or crash the application. These vulnerabilities include out-of-bounds reads, heap-based buffer overflows, null pointer dereference, and integer overflows. The highest impact from these vulnerabilities is to system availability, confidentiality, and integrity. Ghostscript, a PostScript and PDF interpreter, is also vulnerable to a flaw that could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code or cause a denial of service by tricking a user into processing a specially crafted image file. Upgrading to the latest versions of OpenJPEG and Ghostscript is recommended to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in OpenJPEG, Oracle Outside In Technology, and Ghostscript. These vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to cause a denial of service, execute arbitrary code, or compromise the affected systems. The vulnerabilities include null pointer dereference, heap-based buffer overflow, out-of-bounds read and write, use-after-free, and integer overflow. The impact of these vulnerabilities ranges from application crashes to unauthorized ability to cause a hang or frequently repeatable crash. The affected versions include OpenJPEG prior to 2.4.0, Oracle Outside In Technology 8.5.5, and Ghostscript prior to 9.26~dfsg+0-0ubuntu0.18.04.14. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include non-transparent sharing of branch predictor selectors between contexts in some Intel processors, which could potentially enable information disclosure via local access. Other vulnerabilities include flaws in the UDF file system functionality, TIPC protocol functionality, GPU i915 kernel driver functionality, and control groups and namespaces subsystem. These vulnerabilities could allow local or remote attackers to crash the system, escalate privileges, or cause a denial of service. Additionally, a flaw in the NFS4 subsystem could allow a remote NFS4 server to starve resources, impacting system availability. Software mitigations have been implemented for some of these vulnerabilities, and updates are available to address the issues. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

The greatest impact of these flaws is to application availability, with some potential impact to data integrity as well. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A flaw was found in the Linux kernel that can lead to a denial of service (DoS) if an extent tree is corrupted in a crafted ext4 filesystem. By fabricating an integer overflow, a local attacker with special user privileges can cause a system crash, resulting in an availability threat. Another vulnerability in the NFC LLCP protocol implementation allows a local attacker to cause a DoS by exploiting reference counting errors, memory deallocation issues, and error handling flaws. Additionally, the Realtek RTL8188EU Wireless device driver, btrfs file system implementation, perf subsystem, RPA PCI Hotplug driver, Qualcomm IPC router implementation, block device manager (dm), CIPSO implementation, ext4 file system implementation, and IEEE 1394 (Firewire) nosy packet sniffer driver are also vulnerable to DoS attacks or possible code execution. Upgrading to the specified package versions is recommended to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in the Linux kernel, Intel processors, and Amazon Linux AMI and Amazon Linux 2. These vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to obtain sensitive information, cause a denial of service, or execute arbitrary code. The vulnerabilities include non-transparent sharing of branch predictor selectors between contexts in some Intel processors, a flaw in the Linux kernel's UDF file system functionality, a stack overflow flaw in the TIPC protocol functionality, and a random memory access flaw in the GPU i915 kernel driver functionality. Additionally, vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel's control groups and namespaces subsystem and NFS4 subsystem have been identified. Software updates are available to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a random memory access flaw in the GPU i915 kernel driver, a double-free vulnerability in the Packet network protocol implementation, a race condition in the Unix domain socket implementation, a calculation error in the XFS file system, a race condition in the NFC Controller Interface (NCI) implementation, a validation issue in the aQuantia AQtion Ethernet device driver, a TLB flush issue in the Intel i915 graphics driver, and a stale entry issue in the VMware Virtual GPU driver. These vulnerabilities could allow a local attacker to crash the system, escalate privileges, execute arbitrary code, or expose sensitive information. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities related to the Linux kernel's handling of branch predictors in certain Intel processors, which could potentially enable information disclosure. It is recommended to upgrade to the specified package versions to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A use-after-free vulnerability was found in the Linux kernel's memstick driver. This vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2022-0487, exists in the rtsx_usb_ms_drv_remove function in drivers/memstick/host/rtsx_usb_ms.c. An attacker with local user privileges can exploit this flaw to impact system confidentiality. The vulnerability affects kernel versions prior to 5.14 rc1. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A vulnerability has been discovered in the Linux kernel's UDF file system functionality, allowing a local user to crash the system. By triggering the udf_file_write_iter function with a malicious UDF image, a null pointer dereference occurs, leading to a system crash. This vulnerability affects Linux kernel versions 4.2-rc1 to 5.17-rc2. Another vulnerability in the Linux kernel's NFS implementation allows a local attacker to expose sensitive information by opening a directory on a regular file. Additionally, there are several other vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel that could lead to denial of service, privilege escalation, or information disclosure. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A memory leak flaw was found in the Linux kernel's DMA subsystem, allowing a local user to read random memory from the kernel space. This vulnerability can be exploited by calling DMA_FROM_DEVICE function, enabling an attacker to obtain sensitive information and potentially launch further attacks against the affected system. Another vulnerability was discovered in the netfilter subsystem, where a local attacker could cause a denial of service or execute arbitrary code by exploiting the improper validation of passed user register indices. Additionally, multiple use-after-free vulnerabilities were found in various components of the Linux kernel, including the FUSE file system, ALSA framework, USB Gadget file system interface, ST21NFCA NFC driver, and Xilinx USB2 device gadget driver. These vulnerabilities could lead to system crashes or the execution of arbitrary code. Other vulnerabilities include a NULL pointer dereference flaw in the vmxnet3 networking sub-component, a flaw in the X86 CPU Power management options functionality, a NULL pointer dereference in the slip driver, a seccomp permissions mishandling issue, a use-after-free vulnerability in the proxied virtualized TPM devices, and a double-free flaw in the ems_usb_start_xmit function. Lastly, an integer coercion error in the openvswitch kernel module could allow a local user to crash the system or potentially escalate privileges. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel, which could allow an attacker to cause a denial of service, obtain sensitive information, or escalate privileges. These vulnerabilities include a use-after-free flaw in net/netfilter/nf_tables_core.c:nft_do_chain, a memory initialization issue in the netfilter subsystem, and a kernel-infoleak problem in SCTP sockets. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in various kernel components such as the nouveau graphics driver, Spectre Variant 2 mitigations for AMD processors, MMC/SD subsystem, USB gadget subsystem, Remote NDIS (RNDIS) USB gadget implementation, ST21NFCA NFC driver, and Xilinx USB2 device gadget driver. An attacker with local or physical access could exploit these vulnerabilities to crash the system, expose sensitive information, or execute arbitrary code. A security update is available to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
