subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel before version 5.16.12 has multiple vulnerabilities that could allow attackers to obtain sensitive information, execute arbitrary code, or cause denial of service. These vulnerabilities include a flaw in the drivers/net/usb/sr9700.c that allows attackers to obtain sensitive information from heap memory via crafted frame lengths from a device, insufficient Spectre Variant 2 mitigations for AMD processors on Linux, improper access rights restriction in Xen para-virtualization device frontends, use-after-free vulnerability in the USB Gadget file system interface, improper validation of interface descriptor requests in the USB gadget subsystem, improper validation of the size of the RNDIS_MSG_SET command in the Remote NDIS (RNDIS) USB gadget implementation, improper validation of certain data in EVT_TRANSACTION events in the ST21NFCA NFC driver, improper validation of the length of requests from the USB SR9700 ethernet device driver, and improper validation of endpoint indices from the Xilinx USB2 device gadget driver. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple weaknesses that could allow attackers to bypass security restrictions, cause denial of service, or expose sensitive information. These vulnerabilities include improper validation of endpoint index in the USB gadget subsystem, use-after-free in the nouveau graphics driver, insufficient Spectre Variant 2 mitigations for AMD processors, uninitialized memory in the netfilter subsystem, improper handling of read errors from SD cards in the MMC/SD subsystem, and more. An attacker could exploit these vulnerabilities to manipulate endpoint indices, crash the system, or expose sensitive information. A local attacker with privileged access or physical proximity to the target system could exploit these vulnerabilities. A specific version of the Linux kernel (5.16.12) or higher is recommended to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel before version 5.17.9 has a vulnerability that allows TCP servers to identify clients by observing the source ports used. This can lead to the exposure of sensitive information and potential further attacks. Additionally, there are several other vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel, including a framebuffer driver flaw that can result in a denial of service or arbitrary code execution, a race condition in the perf subsystem that can lead to a denial of service or arbitrary code execution, a flaw in the device-mapper verity driver that can cause a denial of service or arbitrary code execution, and a netfilter subsystem issue that can cause a denial of service. There are also vulnerabilities related to insufficient randomization in the IP implementation, a use-after-free vulnerability in the perf subsystem, and a failure to properly verify targets in the device-mapper table. These vulnerabilities can result in various impacts such as system crashes, privilege escalation, information leaks, and denial of service. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple flaws that could allow an attacker to gain elevated privileges, cause denial of service (DoS), or execute arbitrary code. These vulnerabilities include a lack of object validation in the Nouveau DRM subsystem, double-free vulnerabilities in the DRM subsystem, error propagation issues in the Xen paravirtualization backend, error handling issues in multiple Xen backends, memory deallocation issues in the Xen paravirtualization backend and the video4linux subsystem, receive queue overrun issue in the Freescale Gianfar Ethernet driver, race conditions in the USB/IP driver and the netfilter subsystem, and memory deallocation issue in the video4linux subsystem. An attacker with local access and root privileges could exploit these vulnerabilities to escalate privileges, crash the system, or execute code in the kernel's context. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a flaw in the timerqueue_add function, an out-of-bounds memory write flaw, a cBPF JIT compiler flaw, a memory leak flaw in the ccp_run_aes_gcm_cmd() function, a memory leak flaw in the ccp-ops crypto driver, a use-after-free flaw in the USB High Speed Mobile Devices functionality, and a race condition flaw in the OverlayFS subsystem. These vulnerabilities could allow local attackers with special user privileges to cause a denial of service, slow down or crash the system, escalate privileges, or execute arbitrary kernel code. subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a race condition accessing file objects in the OverlayFS subsystem, a missing check for a negative dentry in the OverlayFS subsystem, a use-after-free vulnerability in the NFC subsystem, an integer overflow in the eBPF implementation, a race condition in the timer implementation, and a use-after-free vulnerability in the USB High Speed Mobile Devices functionality. These vulnerabilities could allow a local attacker to crash the system, execute arbitrary code, or escalate privileges. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities related to the hugetlb implementation and the ISDN CAPI implementation. A specific vulnerability, CVE-2021-20321, affects the kernel version 5.10.189.1-1. It is recommended to upgrade to the latest available version of the affected packages. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A vulnerability has been discovered in the Linux kernel's HCI device initialization subsystem, specifically in the handling of user-attached malicious HCI TTY Bluetooth devices. This flaw allows a local user to crash the system by exploiting a double-free memory corruption. Additionally, a use-after-free vulnerability exists in the HCI subsystem, which can be triggered by detaching a Bluetooth dongle or unregistering a Bluetooth device, potentially leading to system crashes or privilege escalation. Another vulnerability affects the BPF subsystem, allowing an attacker to bypass Spectre mitigations and read arbitrary kernel memory. Furthermore, a use-after-free flaw in the Bluetooth host controller interface (HCI) can be exploited by a local attacker to cause a denial of service. The Linux kernel's handling of the removal of Bluetooth HCI controllers is also vulnerable to a race condition, leading to memory corruption and possible privilege escalation. Additionally, a denial-of-service flaw has been identified in the netfilter subsystem due to an incorrect memory barrier. Lastly, improper access control in BlueZ may enable an authenticated user to disclose information or impersonate devices in certain Bluetooth protocols. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability, known as OVE-20180430-0001, exists in the mpatch_decode function in Mercurial before version 4.6.1. It occurs when there should be at least 12 bytes remaining after the current position in the patch data, but actually are not. This error can be exploited by an attacker to cause a denial of service or other unspecified impact. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel. The first vulnerability (CVE-2023-28772) is caused by a buffer overflow in lib/seq_buf.c, allowing an attacker to execute arbitrary code. The second vulnerability (CVE-2021-3655) is due to missing size validations on inbound SCTP packets, which may allow an attacker to read uninitialized memory. The third vulnerability (CVE-2021-35477) is a flaw in the eBPF subsystem that allows a privileged BPF program to obtain sensitive information from kernel memory via a Speculative Store Bypass side-channel. The fourth vulnerability (CVE-2021-34556) is also related to the BPF subsystem, where an unprivileged BPF program can obtain sensitive information from kernel memory via a Speculative Store Bypass side-channel attack. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to confidentiality. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A flaw was found in the Linux kernel's OverlayFS subsystem in the way the user mounts the TmpFS filesystem with OverlayFS. This flaw allows a local user to gain access to hidden files that should not be accessible. Another vulnerability was found in the KVM hypervisor implementation in the Linux kernel, which did not properly perform reference counting in some situations, leading to a use-after-free vulnerability. An attacker who could start and control a VM could possibly use this to expose sensitive information or execute arbitrary code. Additionally, the tracing subsystem in the Linux kernel did not properly keep track of per-cpu ring buffer state, allowing a privileged attacker to cause a denial of service. The MAX-3421 host USB device driver in the Linux kernel did not properly handle device removal events, which could be exploited by a physically proximate attacker to cause a system crash. The Xilinx 10/100 Ethernet Lite device driver in the Linux kernel could report pointer addresses in some situations, which could aid in the exploitation of another vulnerability. Lastly, there are several vulnerabilities affecting different versions of the Linux kernel, including a race condition in the ext4 subsystem, a flaw in computing the access permissions of a shadow page, and an out-of-bounds read flaw in VT. These vulnerabilities could lead to data confidentiality and integrity issues, denial of service, and the disclosure of sensitive information. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A use-after-free vulnerability has been discovered in the Linux kernel's Bluetooth subsystem, allowing a local attacker to crash the system or escalate their privileges. This vulnerability can be exploited by a user calling connect to the socket and disconnect simultaneously due to a race condition. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to confidentiality, integrity, as well as system availability. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in libcurl and curl, which could allow an attacker to exploit various security weaknesses. These vulnerabilities include improper path name validation, bad connection reuse, handling of TELNET connections, and handling of credentials and file hash mismatches when downloading content using the Metalink feature. The impact of these vulnerabilities ranges from potential disclosure of sensitive information to unauthorized access and integrity compromise. It is recommended to upgrade to the latest versions of the affected packages to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: MIT Kerberos 5 (aka krb5) before version 1.17 is vulnerable to a Reachable Assertion issue in the Key Distribution Center (KDC). An attacker who can obtain a krbtgt ticket using an older encryption type (single-DES, triple-DES, or RC4) can crash the KDC by making an S4U2Self request. This vulnerability can be exploited to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: MIT krb5 1.6 or later is vulnerable to a denial of service (NULL pointer dereference) or bypass of a DN container check in the LDAP Kerberos database. An authenticated kadmin with permission to add principals can exploit this vulnerability by supplying tagged data that is internal to the database module. This issue could potentially allow a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information or cause a denial of service. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: MIT krb5 1.6 or later allows an authenticated kadmin with permission to add principals to an LDAP Kerberos database to circumvent a DN containership check by supplying both a "linkdn" and "containerdn" database argument, or by supplying a DN string which is a left extension of a container DN string but is not hierarchically within the container DN. This vulnerability could be exploited by a remote authenticated attacker to bypass security restrictions and obtain sensitive information. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The node-tar package prior to version 6.2.1 has a vulnerability that allows an attacker to consume memory on the system running node-tar and crash the Node.js client by creating a large number of sub-folders during the folder creation process. This can be exploited by providing a path with too many sub-folders inside. An attacker can trigger this vulnerability by sending a specially crafted request. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: MIT Kerberos 5 (aka krb5) before 1.18.5 and 1.19.x before 1.19.3 is vulnerable to a NULL pointer dereference in kdc/do_tgs_req.c via a FAST inner body that lacks a server field. This vulnerability can be exploited by a remote authenticated attacker to cause a denial of service condition. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: OpenLDAP versions 2.x before 2.5.12 and 2.6.x before 2.6.2 are vulnerable to a SQL injection attack in the experimental back-sql backend. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by sending specially-crafted SQL statements within an LDAP query, allowing them to view, add, modify, or delete information in the back-end database. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The nghttp2 package, specifically versions >= 1.10.0 and <= v1.31.0, is vulnerable to an Improper Input Validation CWE-20 vulnerability in ALTSVC frame handling. This vulnerability can be exploited by a remote attacker to cause a segmentation fault, resulting in denial of service. Additionally, there is a NULL pointer dereference vulnerability that can be exploited by sending a specially-crafted packet, causing the application to crash. These vulnerabilities have been fixed in version >= 1.31.1. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability exists in libssh2 v1.9.0 and earlier versions, specifically in the SSH_MSG_DISCONNECT logic in packet.c. It is caused by an integer overflow in a bounds check, allowing an attacker to specify an arbitrary offset for a subsequent memory read. This can lead to the disclosure of sensitive information or a denial of service condition when a user connects to a crafted SSH server. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: LibTiff v4.0.10 is vulnerable to multiple issues, including a heap-based buffer overflow in the '_TIFFmemcpy' function in 'tif_unix.c', which can be exploited by attackers to cause a denial of service (DoS) by persuading a victim to open a specially-crafted TIFF file. Additionally, LibTIFF has other vulnerabilities, such as improper termination of function execution, memory management issues, and failure to perform checks to avoid division calculations with a zero denominator. These vulnerabilities can also lead to DoS or expose sensitive information. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability exists in the libtiff library versions 3.9.0 to 4.3.0, specifically in the memcpy() function within the TIFFFetchStripThing() in tif_dirread.c. It is caused by a null source pointer passed as an argument to memcpy(). This vulnerability could be exploited by an attacker with local authenticated access to a crafted TIFF file, leading to a denial of service. The vulnerability has been assigned CVE-2022-0561. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Express.js, a minimalist web framework for Node.js, is vulnerable to a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack. The vulnerability exists in versions prior to 4.20.0, where passing untrusted user input to the `response.redirect()` function can result in the execution of untrusted code. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by crafting a malicious URL that, when clicked by a victim, executes a script within the security context of the hosting website. This can lead to the theft of the victim's cookie-based authentication credentials. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Versions of Express.js prior to 4.19.0 and all pre-release alpha and beta versions of 5.0 are affected by an open redirect vulnerability using malformed URLs. When a user of Express performs a redirect using a user-provided URL, Express performs an encode using `encodeurl` on the contents before passing it to the `location` header. This can cause malformed URLs to be evaluated in unexpected ways by common redirect allow list implementations in Express applications, leading to an Open Redirect via bypass of a properly implemented allow list. The main method impacted is `res.location()` but this is also called from within `res.redirect()`. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A vulnerability has been identified in the Express response.links function, allowing for arbitrary resource injection in the Link header when unsanitized data is used. The issue arises from improper sanitization in Link header values, which can allow a combination of characters like ',', ';', and '<>' to preload malicious resources. This vulnerability is especially relevant for dynamic parameters. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Express web framework for Node.js versions before 3.11 and 4.x before 4.5 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks. This is due to the framework not providing a charset field in HTTP Content-Type headers in 400 level responses. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by injecting malicious scripts into a web page, which will be executed in the victim's browser within the security context of the hosting website. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The connect node module before version 2.14.0 and the Node.js simple-server module are both vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. The vulnerabilities are caused by a lack of validation of user-supplied input, allowing remote attackers to inject malicious scripts into web pages. When these pages are viewed, the scripts are executed in the victim's web browser within the security context of the hosting website. This could lead to the theft of cookie-based authentication credentials. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Upgrade to the latest version of Debian Node-Connect, to Sencha Connect version 2.14.0 or later or to Connect Connect version 2.14.0 or later. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Sencha Labs Connect middleware in node-connect before version 2.8.2 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks. This vulnerability is due to an incomplete fix for CVE-2013-7370. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by using a specially-crafted URL with the _method parameter to execute malicious scripts in a victim's web browser. This can lead to the theft of the victim's authentication credentials. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Upgrade to the latest version of Debian Node-Connect, to Sencha Connect version 2.8.2 or later or to Connect Connect version 2.8.2 or later. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The http-cache-semantics package in Node.js is vulnerable to a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) flaw. This vulnerability can be exploited by sending specially-crafted request header values to a server that reads the cache policy from the request using this library. An attacker can cause a denial of service condition by exploiting this vulnerability. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The `hosted-git-info` package before version 3.0.8 is vulnerable to a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attack. The vulnerability exists in the `shortcutMatch` regular expression in the `fromUrl` function in `index.js`. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by sending a specially-crafted regex input, causing a denial of service condition. The affected regular expression has a polynomial worst-case time complexity. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Minimist module in Node.js versions prior to 1.2.6 and 0.2.4 is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. This vulnerability exists in the `setKey()` function in the `index.js` script, allowing a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the system. By sending a specially-crafted request, an attacker can exploit this vulnerability. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability exists in the libtiff library versions 4.0 to 4.3.0, where a null source pointer passed as an argument to the memcpy() function within the TIFFReadDirectory() in tif_dirread.c could lead to a denial of service (DoS) via a crafted TIFF file. This vulnerability can be exploited by a local authenticated attacker to cause a crash and disrupt the availability of the system. The vulnerability has been assigned CVE-2022-0562. [Generated by AI]

The vulnerability is caused by the splitDeviceRe, splitTailRe, and splitPathRe regular expressions, which exhibit polynomial worst-case time complexity. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: An issue was discovered in GNOME GLib before 2.66.8. When g_file_replace() is used with G_FILE_CREATE_REPLACE_DESTINATION to replace a path that is a dangling symlink, it incorrectly also creates the target of the symlink as an empty file, which could conceivably have security relevance if the symlink is attacker-controlled. This vulnerability could allow a remote attacker to bypass security restrictions and overwrite arbitrary files on the system by persuading a victim to open a specially-crafted ZIP archive. GLib is a core application building block for libraries and applications written in C, providing the core object system used in GNOME, the main loop implementation, and utility functions for strings and common data structures. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: LibTIFF versions prior to 4.3.0 are vulnerable to multiple security issues, including out-of-bounds read, denial of service, and heap buffer overflow vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities can be exploited by an attacker through specially crafted TIFF files, leading to crashes, denial of service conditions, and potential exposure of sensitive information. The vulnerabilities include CVE-2022-0561, CVE-2022-0562, CVE-2022-0865, CVE-2022-0924, CVE-2022-1355, CVE-2022-22844, CVE-2022-0891, CVE-2022-0908, CVE-2022-0909, and CVE-2022-1354. The impact of these vulnerabilities ranges from denial of service to arbitrary code execution, with potential confidentiality and integrity risks. Upgrading to version 4.3.0-2 or later is recommended to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

This can cause unintended length truncation, leading to application crashes or possible arbitrary code execution. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: DjVuLibre versions 3.5.28 and earlier are vulnerable to a stack-based buffer overflow in the DJVU::DjVuDocument::get_djvu_file function. This flaw can be exploited by a remote attacker by tricking a user into opening a specially-crafted DjVu file, leading to application crashes and other consequences. Additionally, DjVuLibre mishandles certain memory operations, which can result in denial of service or arbitrary code execution if a specially crafted DjVu file is processed. A security update is available to fix these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability in libxml2 versions 2.9.4 and earlier, as used in XMLSec 1.2.23 and other products, allows remote attackers to conduct XML External Entity (XXE) attacks by exploiting the failure to offer a flag indicating that the current document may be read but other files may not be opened. This can lead to the disclosure of sensitive information. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability is an input validation issue in the Common UNIX Printing System (CUPS) component of Apple macOS. It allows a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information by exploiting improper input validation. This can be done by persuading a victim to open a specially-crafted application, which enables the attacker to access restricted memory information. The vulnerability affects macOS Mojave 10.14.6 and macOS Catalina 10.15.7. It has been fixed in macOS Big Sur 11.1, Security Update 2020-001 Catalina, and Security Update 2020-007 Mojave. Additionally, the vulnerability also affects Ubuntu 18.04 LTS and Ubuntu 20.04 LTS, but it has been addressed with the update instructions provided in the description. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Avahi versions 0.6 up to 0.8 are vulnerable to a flaw that allows a local attacker to trigger an infinite loop by exploiting the mishandling of the termination signal on the avahi Unix socket. This flaw results in the unresponsiveness of the avahi service. Additionally, Avahi is susceptible to a denial of service attack caused by an unresponsive busy-loop of the daemon. By sending a specially-crafted request, a local attacker can exploit this vulnerability to cause a denial of service. Avahi is an implementation of the DNS Service Discovery and Multicast DNS specifications for Zero Configuration Networking, facilitating service discovery on a local network. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability is an integer overflow in xmlmemory.c in libxml2 before 2.9.5, which is used in Google Chrome and other products. It allows a remote attacker to potentially exploit heap corruption via a crafted XML file. This can lead to a heap-based buffer overflow in Google Chrome, causing the application to crash or allowing the attacker to execute arbitrary code on the system. The vulnerability also affects the Oracle HTTP Server product of Oracle Fusion Middleware, allowing an unauthenticated attacker to compromise the server and potentially take it over. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: ImageMagick is vulnerable to multiple flaws that could lead to data confidentiality breaches and denial of service attacks. The vulnerabilities include a potential cipher leak in calculating signatures, incorrect handling of certain values in visual effects and resampling operations, memory cleanup issues during cryptographic operations, and incorrect handling of thumbnail image data. These vulnerabilities could be exploited by an attacker to obtain sensitive information, crash the application, or disclose cryptographic information. A local attacker could exploit the cipher leak vulnerability to obtain sensitive information and launch further attacks. By tricking a user into opening a specially crafted image file, an attacker could crash the application, causing a denial of service. No workarounds or mitigations are available for these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: ImageMagick versions 7.0.11 and earlier are vulnerable to an integer overflow in the WriteTHUMBNAILImage function of coders/thumbnail.c. This flaw can be exploited by an attacker who submits a crafted image file to an application using ImageMagick, resulting in undefined behavior. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: ImageMagick versions before 7.0.11 and before 6.9.12 are vulnerable to multiple denial of service (DoS) vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities include a division by zero in WaveImage() of MagickCore/visual-effects.c, incorrect handling of certain values when processing visual effects based image files, and incorrect memory cleanup when performing certain cryptographic operations. An attacker can exploit these vulnerabilities by tricking a user into opening a specially crafted image file, causing the application to crash and resulting in a DoS condition. The highest threat from these vulnerabilities is to system availability. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

The highest threat from these vulnerabilities is to system availability. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: ImageMagick is vulnerable to multiple denial of service vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities include division by zero, incorrect handling of certain values, and memory management issues. An attacker could exploit these vulnerabilities by tricking a user into opening a specially crafted file, resulting in a denial of service condition. In some cases, sensitive information could be disclosed. The vulnerabilities affect various versions of Ubuntu, including 14.04 ESM, 16.04 ESM, 18.04 LTS, and 22.10. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: ImageMagick is vulnerable to a flaw in MagickCore/quantum-export.c, where a crafted file could trigger undefined behavior and cause values outside the range of type `unsigned long long` as well as a shift exponent that is too large for 64-bit type. This vulnerability could lead to application availability issues and potentially other problems related to undefined behavior. The vulnerability affects ImageMagick versions prior to 7.0.9-0. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A vulnerability has been discovered in Python's FTP client library in PASV mode, allowing an attacker to set up a malicious FTP server and trick FTP clients into connecting back to a specified IP address and port. This could enable the attacker to scan ports that would otherwise be inaccessible. Additionally, another flaw in the FTP client library could allow an attacker to obtain sensitive information by exploiting a specially-crafted FTP server. These vulnerabilities could lead to further attacks against the affected system. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability in libxml2 allows for an exponential entity expansion attack that bypasses existing protection mechanisms, leading to a denial of service. It can be exploited remotely by a authenticated attacker to consume all available resources. Additionally, there are other vulnerabilities such as error handling issues, invalid UTF-8 input handling, and crafted XML file handling that can cause denial of service or even arbitrary code execution. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The package python/cpython is vulnerable to Web Cache Poisoning via urllib.parse.parse_qsl and urllib.parse.parse_qs by using a vector called parameter cloaking. When the attacker can separate query parameters using a semicolon (;), they can cause a difference in the interpretation of the request between the proxy (running with default configuration) and the server. This can result in malicious requests being cached as completely safe ones, as the proxy would usually not see the semicolon as a separator, and therefore would not include it in a cache key of an unkeyed parameter. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
additionalData: {"cveDescriptionAdditionalInformation":"The python36 component in the python36:3.6 module in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8 is not affected, as it does not contain the vulnerable Python interpreter or libraries. Red Hat Ceph Storage (RHCS) 3 ships an older version of python-django without the directly affected function, but which is still vulnerable to a similar attack involving the semicolon separator. Red Hat OpenStack Platform 13 & 16.1 ship the affected code, but the impact has been lowered to Low as the proxy is controlled and configured by OpenStack. subAssessmentDescription: The Python documentation XML-RPC server is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks via the server_title field. This vulnerability exists in Python versions 2.7.16 through 2.7.17, 3.x through 3.6.9, and 3.7.x through 3.7.4. An attacker can inject arbitrary JavaScript into a web page, which will be executed in the victim's browser when the URL is clicked. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The libxml2 library before version 2.9.13 is vulnerable to a use-after-free of ID and IDREF attributes. This vulnerability can be exploited by a remote attacker to cause a denial of service or execute arbitrary code. The vulnerability affects multiple Oracle Communications Cloud Native Core products, Oracle MySQL Workbench, and Apple Watch Series 3 and later. It can result in unauthorized ability to cause a hang or frequently repeatable crash (complete DOS) of the affected systems. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Versions of the package tough-cookie before 4.1.3 are vulnerable to Prototype Pollution due to improper handling of Cookies when using CookieJar in `rejectPublicSuffixes=false` mode. This issue arises from the manner in which the objects are initialized. By adding or modifying properties of Object.prototype using a __proto__ or constructor payload, an attacker could exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code on the system. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The libxml2 library before version 2.9.14 is vulnerable to integer overflows in buffer handling functions, specifically in buf.c (xmlBuf*) and tree.c (xmlBuffer*). This can lead to out-of-bounds memory writes when a victim opens a specially-crafted XML file, potentially resulting in a denial of service condition. Other software using libxml2's buffer functions, such as libxslt through version 1.1.35, is also affected. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by persuading a victim to open a multi-gigabyte XML file. The impact includes a potential crash, denial of service, or even arbitrary code execution. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

This vulnerability allows a remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) by persuading a victim to open a specially-crafted file. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability affects the Expat library, specifically the xmlparse.c file, in versions before 2.4.5. Attackers can exploit this vulnerability by inserting namespace-separator characters into namespace URIs, potentially leading to a denial of service condition. The Oracle HTTP Server product of Oracle Fusion Middleware is also affected by this vulnerability in version 12.2.1.4.0, allowing unauthenticated attackers with network access via HTTP to compromise the server and potentially take it over. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected. Amazon Linux 2 is also vulnerable to this issue. Another vulnerability, CVE-2022-25235, allows attackers to execute arbitrary code by passing malformed UTF-8 sequences to the XML processor. Aruba products are also affected by these vulnerabilities, potentially leading to denial of service conditions or remote code execution when specially crafted XML input is used. The impact on Aruba products is considered low based on ongoing testing. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The qs module in Node.js versions before 1.0.0 does not properly handle array data, allowing remote attackers to cause a denial of service (memory consumption) by using a large index value to create a sparse array. Additionally, a vulnerability in the qs module when parsing a string representing a deeply nested object can be exploited by an attacker to block the event loop for an extended period of time, resulting in a denial of service. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The web framework using ljharb's qs module older than v6.3.2, v6.2.3, v6.1.2, and v6.0.4 is vulnerable to a Denial of Service (DoS) attack. A malicious user can send a specially-crafted request to cause the web framework to crash. Additionally, the affected version of `qs` is also vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. This vulnerability allows an attacker to bypass the protection and alter the Object prototype by using input containing `[` or `]`. This can lead to Denial of Service or Remote Code Execution in specific circumstances. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The qs module before version 1.0.0 of Node.js does not have an option or default for specifying object depth. This vulnerability allows an attacker to send a deeply nested JSON string, causing the event loop to block for extended periods of time. As a result, a temporary denial-of-service condition can be triggered, preventing other requests from being processed. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Upgrade to the latest version of Debian Node-Qs, to Qs Project Qs version 1.0.0 or later or to Qs Qs version 1.0.0 or later. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Request package through 2.88.1 for Node.js and the @cypress/request package prior to 3.0.0 are vulnerable to a bypass of server-side request forgery (SSRF) mitigations. This is due to a cross-protocol redirect bypass flaw, which allows an attacker-controlled server to redirect requests from HTTP to HTTPS or from HTTPS to HTTP. This vulnerability can be exploited to conduct SSRF attacks. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The semver package in Node.js versions before 7.5.2, 6.3.1, and 5.7.2 is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks. This vulnerability occurs when untrusted user data is provided as a range in the new Range function. An attacker can exploit this flaw by providing specially crafted regex input, leading to a denial of service. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple weaknesses that could be exploited by attackers to launch further attacks, cause denial of service (system crash), execute arbitrary code, gain elevated privileges, or expose sensitive information. These vulnerabilities include an implementation error of random seed data, null pointer dereference, improper validation of meta-data and xattr information in filesystem implementations, stack-based buffer overflow, race conditions, buffer overflow in extended attributes handling, permission checks in nested virtualization, error handling in exception handling, information leak in the generic SCSI driver, and integer overflow in the VESA frame buffer driver. Additionally, vulnerabilities were found in the ARM Advanced Microcontroller Bus Architecture (AMBA) driver and the USB/IP implementation. These vulnerabilities can be fixed by updating the system to the specified package versions. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA, WPA2, and WPA3) and Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) protocols have a vulnerability where not all fragments of a frame are encrypted under the same key. This allows an attacker to decrypt selected fragments when another device sends fragmented frames and the encryption key is periodically renewed. Microsoft Windows is also vulnerable to a flaw in the Wireless Networking component, which allows a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information and launch further attacks against the system. Additionally, the Linux kernel has multiple vulnerabilities, including race conditions, use-after-free vulnerabilities, and memory access flaws in the CAN BCM networking protocol, eBPF implementation, and WiFi implementation. These vulnerabilities could allow a local attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service, inject packets, or expose sensitive information. Intel has also identified potential security vulnerabilities in some Intel PROSet/Wireless WiFi and Intel vPro CSME WiFi and Killer WiFi, which may allow denial of service. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Expat (aka libexpat) before version 2.4.3 is vulnerable to a realloc misbehavior issue in the storeAtts function in xmlparse.c. This vulnerability can be exploited by persuading a victim to open a specially-crafted XML content, leading to a denial of service (application crash). The vulnerability occurs when there is a left shift by 29 or more places, causing realloc misbehavior such as allocating too few bytes or only freeing memory. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to cause the application to crash or potentially execute arbitrary code. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel versions 5.8.9 and earlier, as well as multiple Cisco products, are vulnerable to a flaw that allows an attacker to inject packets or exfiltrate selected fragments. This vulnerability occurs when the WEP, WPA, WPA2, or WPA3 implementations reassemble fragments that were sent in plaintext. An attacker can exploit this weakness by sending specially-crafted requests. Additionally, the Linux kernel is affected by several other vulnerabilities, including use-after-free vulnerabilities in the CAN BCM networking protocol, a failure to enforce limits for pointer operations in the eBPF implementation, and various issues in the WiFi implementation that could lead to packet injection, decryption, or exposure of sensitive information. There are also vulnerabilities in the SCTP implementation, the nfc implementation, the Bluetooth subsystem, and the f2fs module. These vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service, or expose sensitive information. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The c_rehash script in OpenSSL does not properly sanitize shell metacharacters, allowing for command injection. This script is distributed by some operating systems and can be automatically executed, enabling an attacker to execute arbitrary commands with the privileges of the script. The use of the c_rehash script is considered obsolete and should be replaced by the OpenSSL rehash command line tool. The vulnerability has been fixed in OpenSSL versions 3.0.3, 1.1.1o, and 1.0.2ze. subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability in OpenSSL (CVE-2021-3712) allows for a read buffer overrun when processing ASN.1 strings. This occurs when applications directly construct ASN1_STRING structures without NUL terminating the byte array. As a result, a malicious actor can exploit this vulnerability to cause a crash or disclose sensitive information, such as private keys or plaintext. The issue affects OpenSSL versions 1.1.1-1.1.1k and 1.0.2-1.0.2y. Additionally, Oracle Communications Cloud Native Core Console, Security Edge Protection Proxy, Unified Data Repository, Session Border Controller, Unified Session Manager, Enterprise Communications Broker, and Enterprise Session Border Controller are also affected, allowing unauthorized access to critical data or causing a denial of service. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected. The vulnerability can be remediated by upgrading to OpenSSL 1.1.1l or 1.0.2za. For Oracle Communications products, upgrading to the fixed versions is recommended. Aruba advises upgrading to specific versions to address vulnerabilities in AOS-CX. Siemens recommends updating to the specified versions for SINUMERIK, PCS neo, PCS 7, WinCC, and other products. Amazon Linux AMI and Amazon Linux 2 provide package updates to fix the vulnerability. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: There is an overflow bug in the x64_64 Montgomery squaring procedure used in exponentiation with 512-bit moduli in OpenSSL. This vulnerability could allow a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information. The affected versions are OpenSSL 1.1.1-1.1.1d and OpenSSL 1.0.2-1.0.2t. The vulnerability has been fixed in OpenSSL 1.1.1e and OpenSSL 1.0.2u. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Bluetooth LE and BR/EDR secure pairing in Bluetooth Core Specification 2.1 through 5.2 may permit a nearby man-in-the-middle attacker to identify the Passkey used during pairing by reflection of the public key and the authentication evidence of the initiating device, potentially allowing the attacker to complete authenticated pairing with the responding device using the correct Passkey for the pairing session. Additionally, there are multiple vulnerabilities in the BlueZ software, including improper permission checks when pairing, redundant disconnect MGMT events, and mishandling of certain array indexes, which could lead to device impersonation, denial of service, or information disclosure. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel before version 5.7.3 has multiple vulnerabilities that could allow local attackers to bypass security restrictions, cause denial of service, execute arbitrary code, or gain unintended read or write access to memory. These vulnerabilities include a flaw in the copy-on-write (CoW) fault handler, a use-after-free in the Sun keyboard driver implementation, an out-of-bounds read vulnerability in the jfs file system implementation, a handling issue in the Speakup screen reader driver, a memory management issue, a limitation issue in the Xen event processing backend, a race condition in the Xen paravirt block backend, a locking issue in the tty subsystem, and a race condition in the tty subsystem. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in the eBPF verification code, the Spectre mitigation mechanism, and the SCTP socket functionality. The impact of these vulnerabilities ranges from privilege escalation and information disclosure to denial of service and arbitrary code execution. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Python is vulnerable to multiple flaws that could result in denial of service (DoS) attacks. The first vulnerability involves improper handling of HTTP responses in the HTTP client code, allowing a remote attacker to make the client script enter an infinite loop, consuming CPU time and impacting system availability. The second vulnerability is related to the urllib.request.AbstractBasicAuthHandler class, which contains a regular expression with a quadratic worst-case time complexity. A malicious HTTP server could exploit this flaw to cause a denial of service condition for a client. Additionally, there are other vulnerabilities such as web cache poisoning, injection attacks, and issues with the ftplib module. These vulnerabilities could be exploited by remote attackers to disrupt the availability of the affected systems. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability exists in the urllib's AbstractBasicAuthHandler class in Python, which can be exploited by an attacker who controls a malicious HTTP server. By sending a specially crafted payload during an authentication request, the attacker can trigger a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDOS) condition, potentially causing a denial of service and impacting application availability. Another vulnerability in the Python urllib HTTP client allows an attacker to cause an infinite loop by manipulating certain server responses, leading to a denial of service condition for the client. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
additionalData: {"cveDescriptionAdditionalInformation":"The vulnerability in urllib.parse module (CVE-2022-0391) allows injection attacks through crafted URLs. Another vulnerability (CVE-2021-23336) involves Web Cache Poisoning via urllib.parse.parse_qsl and urllib.parse.parse_qs, which can lead to malicious requests being cached as safe ones. There is also a vulnerability in ftplib (CVE-2021-4189) that allows the use of the host from the PASV response. Finally, there is a vulnerability in Python3's Lib/test/multibytecodec_support.py (CVE-2020-27619) where CJK codec tests call eval() on content retrieved via HTTP. subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple security issues, including denial of service, information disclosure, privilege escalation, and data leakage. These vulnerabilities can be exploited by local or remote attackers to crash the system, execute arbitrary code, or escalate privileges. Some of the vulnerabilities include a flaw in the FUSE filesystem implementation that can cause a system crash, a race condition in the Infiniband RDMA userspace connection manager that can lead to a use-after-free vulnerability, and a size validation issue in the SCTP implementation that can expose sensitive information. Other vulnerabilities involve the improper validation of metadata in the Qualcomm IPC Router protocol, a race condition in the virtual terminal device implementation that can expose sensitive information, and a memory exhaustion flaw in the Linux kernel's memory usage accounting. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities related to the f2fs file system, the Aspeed Low Pin Count (LPC) Bus Controller implementation, and the NFSv4 client implementation. The impact of these vulnerabilities ranges from system crashes and denial of service to possible execution of arbitrary code and exposure of sensitive information. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A use-after-free vulnerability was discovered in the Linux kernel's HCI subsystem, specifically in the function sco_sock_sendmsg(). This vulnerability can be triggered by a privileged local user through a race condition with the call sco_conn_del(). By exploiting this flaw, an attacker could crash the system or escalate their privileges. Another use-after-free vulnerability was found in the sco_send_frame function of the Bluetooth subsystem, which could also lead to a denial of service or arbitrary code execution. Additionally, there are several other vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel that could result in various impacts, such as data leakage, privilege escalation, and system crashes. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

Security updates are available to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux Kernel versions 5.4.66 and 5.4.54, including the latest version 5.11-rc4, are vulnerable to an information disclosure vulnerability in the ARM SIGPAGE functionality. This vulnerability allows a userland application to read the contents of the sigpage, potentially leaking kernel memory contents. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by reading a process's memory at a specific offset. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability exists in the opj2_decompress program in openjpeg2, specifically in the way it handles an input directory with a large number of files. When it fails to allocate a buffer to store the filenames of the input directory, it calls free() on an uninitialized pointer, resulting in a segmentation fault and a denial of service. This vulnerability can be exploited remotely by persuading a victim to open a specially-crafted file, causing a denial of service. It affects Oracle Outside In Technology, Oracle Fusion Middleware, and Oracle Database Server. Additionally, OpenJPEG is also vulnerable to an integer overflow vulnerability and a heap-based buffer overflow vulnerability, which can lead to a denial of service and arbitrary code execution respectively. The affected versions include Ubuntu 16.04 LTS, Ubuntu 18.04 LTS, Ubuntu 20.04 LTS, and Ubuntu 22.04 LTS. Amazon Linux 2 is also affected.  [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: OpenJPEG is vulnerable to multiple vulnerabilities that could result in denial of service (DoS) or arbitrary code execution. These vulnerabilities include an integer overflow, heap-based buffer overflow, out-of-bounds read, NULL pointer dereference, and buffer overflow. Attackers can exploit these vulnerabilities by tricking a user into opening a specially crafted file or by submitting a large number of image files to be processed. The impact of these vulnerabilities ranges from application crashes to the execution of arbitrary code with the permissions of the application. Red Hat's versions of the software are not affected by one of the vulnerabilities. Proposed patches are available for some of the vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Sencha Labs Connect before version 2.8.1 is vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) due to an improper fix related to the validation of user-supplied input by the methodOverride middleware. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by using a specially-crafted URL with the _method parameter to execute malicious scripts in a victim's web browser within the security context of the hosting website. This can lead to the theft of the victim's cookie-based authentication credentials. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
additionalData: {"cveDescriptionAdditionalInformation":"Connect is a stack of middleware that is executed in order for each request. The methodOverride middleware allows the HTTP POST method to override the method of the request using the _method post key or the x-http-method-override header. The vulnerability occurs because the user's post input was not properly checked, allowing the req.method to contain any value. As a result, Connect responds with a 404 page that includes the unencoded method value, leading to the XSS vulnerability. subAssessmentDescription: OpenEXR is vulnerable to multiple flaws that could be exploited by an attacker who can submit a crafted file to be processed by OpenEXR. These vulnerabilities include an integer overflow in the dataWindowForTile function, an out-of-bounds read in the rleUncompress functionality, an undefined right shift error in the hufDecode functionality, and an out-of-bounds write on the heap in the dataWindowForTile function. These vulnerabilities could lead to a denial of service and impact application availability, with some potential impact to data integrity. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A vulnerability has been discovered in OpenEXR versions before 3.0.0-beta. The flaw exists in the Dwa decompression functionality of OpenEXR's IlmImf library, where a crafted input file supplied by an attacker could lead to a NULL pointer dereference. This vulnerability could potentially result in a denial of service (DoS) attack, impacting system availability. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: X.Org libX11 versions before 1.7.1 and X through X11R7.7 are vulnerable to remote code execution. The flaw exists in the libX11 XLookupColor request, which allows clients to send color-name requests with a name longer than the maximum size allowed by the protocol. This user-controlled data exceeding the maximum size is then interpreted by the server as additional X protocol requests and executed, potentially leading to the execution of arbitrary code or disabling X server authorization. Exploitation of this vulnerability can result in a complete compromise of the running graphical session. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
additionalData: {"cveDescriptionAdditionalInformation":"Xorg server does not run with root privileges in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8, so the impact is rated as moderate for this version. However, it is still affected in non-default configurations. It is recommended to avoid using xterm to display less trusted data and ensure that the .Xdefaults file is not modifiable by the user. For Amazon Linux AMI and Amazon Linux 2, package updates are available to fix the vulnerability. subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in the Xen hypervisor subsystem of the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a denial of service (DoS) vulnerability caused by high-frequency event attacks in the blkfront, netfront, and hvc_xen (console) backends. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel's network backend driver, USB Gadget subsystem, Unix domain socket implementation, XFS file system implementation, NFC Controller Interface (NCI) implementation, Intel i915 graphics driver, and VMware Virtual GPU driver. These vulnerabilities could lead to DoS, system crashes, arbitrary code execution, information leaks, and privilege escalation. Specific CVEs associated with these vulnerabilities are CVE-2021-28711, CVE-2021-28712, CVE-2021-28713, CVE-2021-28714, CVE-2021-28715, CVE-2021-22600, CVE-2021-39685, CVE-2021-4083, CVE-2021-4155, CVE-2022-0330, and CVE-2022-22942. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple security issues, including improper validation of the size of the RNDIS_MSG_SET command in the RNDIS USB gadget, a use-after-free vulnerability in the nouveau graphics driver, insufficient Spectre Variant 2 mitigations for AMD processors, uninitialized memory in the netfilter subsystem, improper handling of read errors from SD cards in the MMC/SD subsystem, lack of validation in the USB gadget subsystem, and improper validation of certain data in the ST21NFCA NFC driver and Xilinx USB2 device gadget driver. These vulnerabilities could allow attackers to obtain sensitive information from kernel memory, cause a denial of service, or execute arbitrary code. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple security issues. These include a lack of validation in the USB Gadget subsystem, a use-after-free vulnerability in the nouveau graphics driver, insufficient Spectre Variant 2 mitigations for AMD processors, uninitialized memory in the netfilter subsystem, improper handling of read errors from SD cards in the MMC/SD subsystem, and various other vulnerabilities in different drivers and subsystems. These vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to cause a denial of service (system crash), expose sensitive information from kernel memory, or possibly execute arbitrary code. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel through version 5.16.8 has multiple vulnerabilities that could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause a denial of service, or expose sensitive information. These vulnerabilities include a use-after-free flaw in the handling of dev->buf release in drivers/usb/gadget/legacy/inode.c, insufficient Spectre Variant 2 mitigations for AMD processors, improper access rights restriction in Xen para-virtualization device frontends, use-after-free vulnerability in the USB Gadget file system interface, improper validation of interface descriptor requests in the USB gadget subsystem, improper validation of the size of the RNDIS_MSG_SET command in the Remote NDIS (RNDIS) USB gadget implementation, improper validation of certain data in EVT_TRANSACTION events in the ST21NFCA NFC driver, improper validation of the length of requests from the USB SR9700 ethernet device driver, and improper validation of endpoint indices from the host in the Xilinx USB2 device gadget driver. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in various Linux kernels, including Arm Cortex, Neoverse, and Intel processors. These vulnerabilities could allow attackers to obtain sensitive information, cause denial of service, or escalate privileges. One of the vulnerabilities, known as Spectre-BHB or Branch History Injection, allows attackers to influence mispredicted branches and obtain sensitive information through cache allocation. Another vulnerability in Xen allows local authenticated attackers to obtain sensitive information by exploiting the non-transparent sharing of branch predictor selectors. The impact of these vulnerabilities can range from information disclosure to system crashes and privilege escalation. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Upgrade to the latest version of the affected Linux kernel. For Arm Cortex and Neoverse processors, upgrade to a version released after 2022-03-08. For Xen, apply the necessary patches or updates provided by the vendor. For other Linux kernels, upgrade to the latest available version. It is recommended to regularly check for security updates and apply them promptly. [Generated by AI]
additionalData: {"cveDescriptionAdditionalInformation":"Some mitigations have been implemented by default in certain Linux distributions. For example, Red Hat Enterprise Linux disables unprivileged eBPF functionality, which effectively mitigates known attack vectors for exploiting intra-mode branch injection attacks. Amazon Linux kernel enables software mitigations for specific vulnerabilities on ARM-based EC2 instance types. Administrators should review the advisories and documentation provided by their respective Linux distributions for specific instructions and recommendations. subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in Linux PV device frontends and Xen, which could allow attackers to gain unauthorized access to memory pages of a guest VM, cause data leaks or corruption, and trigger denial of service attacks. The affected components include blkfront, netfront, scsifront, gntalloc, and xenbus drivers. Additionally, the Linux kernel is vulnerable to a use-after-free vulnerability in the USB Gadget file system interface, which could lead to system crashes or arbitrary code execution. The ST21NFCA NFC driver, USB SR9700 ethernet device driver, and Xilinx USB2 device gadget driver are also affected by vulnerabilities that could result in denial of service or exposure of sensitive information. These vulnerabilities have been assigned the following CVEs: CVE-2022-23036, CVE-2022-23037, CVE-2022-23038, CVE-2022-23039, CVE-2022-23040, CVE-2022-23041, CVE-2022-23042, CVE-2022-24958, CVE-2022-25258, CVE-2022-25375, CVE-2022-26490, and CVE-2022-26966. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A use-after-free vulnerability was found in the Linux kernel HCI subsystem. This vulnerability can be triggered by user calls to ioct HCIUNBLOCKADDR or other events that cause a race condition with hci_unregister_dev(). A local attacker with privileged access could exploit this flaw to crash the system or escalate their privileges. Another vulnerability in the Linux kernel HCI device initialization subsystem allows a local user to cause a denial of service by attaching a malicious HCI TTY Bluetooth device. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities related to memory corruption, information disclosure, and privilege escalation in the Bluetooth subsystem, BPF subsystem, and netfilter subsystem of the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities could lead to various impacts such as data integrity, confidentiality, and system availability. The affected Linux kernel versions are prior to 5.13-rc5. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in the Xen hypervisor subsystem of the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a denial of service (DoS) issue caused by high-frequency event attacks, a double-free vulnerability in the Packet network protocol implementation, a race condition in the Unix domain socket implementation, a size calculation issue in the XFS file system, a use-after-free vulnerability in the NFC Controller Interface (NCI) implementation, and a failure to perform a GPU TLB flush in the Intel i915 graphics driver. These vulnerabilities could be exploited by local attackers to cause a DoS, execute arbitrary code, or gain elevated privileges. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a guest's ability to force the Linux netback driver to consume large amounts of kernel memory, a denial of service vulnerability in the Xen netback backend driver, a double-free vulnerability in the Packet network protocol implementation, a limitation issue in the Xen subsystem that allows driver domains to send an excessive number of events to other guest VMs, a denial of service vulnerability in the Xen network backend driver, a control request size restriction issue in the USB Gadget subsystem, a race condition in the Unix domain socket implementation, an incorrect size calculation issue in the XFS file system, a race condition in the NFC Controller Interface (NCI) implementation, a GPU TLB flush issue in the Intel i915 graphics driver, and a stale entry issue in the VMware Virtual GPU driver. These vulnerabilities could result in denial of service, system crashes, arbitrary code execution, information exposure, or privilege escalation. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A flaw was found in the Linux kernel's KVM when attempting to set a SynIC IRQ. This issue makes it possible for a misbehaving VMM to write to SYNIC/STIMER MSRs, causing a NULL pointer dereference. This flaw allows an unprivileged local attacker on the host to issue specific ioctl calls, causing a kernel oops condition that results in a denial of service. Another vulnerability was found in the Linux kernel's Netfilter subsystem, allowing a local user to crash the system or a remote user to crash the system when the libnetfilter_queue is used by a local user. Additionally, Intel microprocessor generations 6 to 8 are affected by a new Spectre variant that is able to bypass their retpoline mitigation in the kernel to leak arbitrary data. An attacker with unprivileged user access can hijack return instructions to achieve arbitrary speculative code execution under certain microarchitecture-dependent conditions. There is also a use-after-free flaw in the Linux kernel's Atheros wireless adapter driver, allowing a local user to crash or potentially escalate their privileges on the system. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in Intel processors, specifically related to incomplete cleanup in specific special register write operations and microarchitectural fill buffers. These vulnerabilities could allow an authenticated user to enable information disclosure via local access. The impact of these vulnerabilities is the potential exposure of sensitive information, which could be used to launch further attacks against the affected system. Security updates and firmware updates are available from various vendors, including Intel, Dell, HP, and Lenovo, to mitigate these vulnerabilities. It is recommended to upgrade to the latest available versions provided by the respective vendors. No workarounds have been specified. Please refer to the advisories from the respective vendors for more information. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel before version 5.11.8 is vulnerable to a denial of service (DoS) attack due to an issue in the fs/fuse/fuse_i.h file. This vulnerability allows a local attacker to cause a "stall on CPU" by continuously finding the same bad inode. Additionally, the Linux kernel is also vulnerable to other issues, including a denial of service caused by a reference counting error in the NFC LLCP protocol implementation, a memory deallocation error in the NFC LLCP protocol implementation, an infinite loop in the NFC LLCP protocol implementation, a memory deallocation error in the Xen paravirtualization backend, a bad inode handling issue in the fuse user space file system implementation, a race condition in the btrfs file system implementation, a PEBS records handling issue in the perf subsystem, a buffer overflow in the RPA PCI Hotplug driver implementation, a receive queue overrun issue in the Freescale Gianfar Ethernet driver, a memory initialization issue in the Qualcomm IPC router implementation, a buffer overflow in the block device manager (dm) implementation, and a use-after-free vulnerability in the IEEE 1394 (Firewire) nosy packet sniffer driver. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A NULL pointer dereference flaw was found in the Linux kernel’s X.25 set of standardized network protocols functionality in the way a user terminates their session using a simulated Ethernet card and continued usage of this connection. This flaw allows a local user to crash the system. Another vulnerability allows a local attacker to bypass UEFI Secure Boot restrictions. There are also vulnerabilities that can lead to denial of service (system crash) or execute arbitrary code. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities that can cause a denial of service (connection disassociation), gain administrative privileges, or expose sensitive information (kernel memory). There are also vulnerabilities that can cause a denial of service (system crash) or possibly execute arbitrary code. Furthermore, there are vulnerabilities that can cause a denial of service (system crash) or memory exhaustion. Finally, there are vulnerabilities that can cause a denial of service or reference counting error. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple race condition vulnerabilities, denial of service (DoS) attacks, and memory-related issues. These vulnerabilities could be exploited by local attackers to cause system crashes, memory exhaustion, or disclose sensitive information. The vulnerabilities include a race condition in the btrfs file system implementation, a reference counting error in the NFC LLCP protocol implementation, a buffer overflow in the RPA PCI Hotplug driver, and a use-after-free vulnerability in the IEEE 1394 nosy packet sniffer driver. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in the perf subsystem, Qualcomm IPC router implementation, block device manager (dm) implementation, CIPSO implementation, ext4 file system implementation, and eBPF implementation. Upgrading to the specified package versions is recommended to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple weaknesses that could lead to denial of service (system crash) or memory exhaustion. These vulnerabilities include mishandling of PEBS records, reference counting errors in the NFC LLCP protocol implementation, improper validation of ssid lengths in the Realtek RTL8188EU Wireless device driver, a race condition in the btrfs file system implementation, improper handling of PEBS records in the perf subsystem, buffer overflow in the RPA PCI Hotplug driver implementation, improper initialization of memory in the Qualcomm IPC router implementation, buffer overflow in the block device manager (dm) implementation, use-after-free vulnerabilities in the CIPSO implementation, integer overflow in the ext4 file system implementation, and use-after-free vulnerability in the IEEE 1394 (Firewire) nosy packet sniffer driver. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in Intel processors, specifically related to incomplete cleanup of microarchitectural fill buffers, multi-core shared buffers, and specific special register write operations. These vulnerabilities could allow an authenticated user to enable information disclosure via local access. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel that could lead to privilege escalation, denial of service, and information leaks. The impact of these vulnerabilities includes the potential for sensitive information to be obtained, further attacks to be launched, and compromise of affected systems. Security updates and firmware updates are available to remediate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Upgrade to the latest version of the affected software or firmware. For Intel processors, apply the firmware updates provided by Intel. For the Linux kernel, update to the latest version of the kernel. Specific version numbers are not provided in the advisories. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been identified in various Linux kernels and Intel processors. These vulnerabilities could allow an authenticated user to enable information disclosure, escalate privileges, or cause denial of service. The vulnerabilities include incomplete cleanup of multi-core shared buffers (CVE-2022-21123), incomplete cleanup of microarchitectural fill buffers (CVE-2022-21125), incomplete cleanup in specific special register write operations (CVE-2022-21166), use-after-free vulnerabilities, and buffer overflow vulnerabilities. Exploitation of these vulnerabilities could result in sensitive information exposure, privilege escalation, or system crashes. Security updates and firmware updates are available to address these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Upgrade to the latest version of the Linux kernel or firmware provided by the respective vendors. Apply security updates and firmware updates as soon as possible. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux Kernel is vulnerable to multiple denial of service and use-after-free vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to crash the system or execute arbitrary code. The vulnerabilities include a sleep-in-atomic bug in /net/nfc/netlink.c, a race condition in the network packet scheduler implementation, a use-after-free vulnerability in the netfilter subsystem, a memory initialization issue in the block layer subsystem, race conditions in the Advanced Linux Sound Architecture (ALSA) framework, race conditions in the 6pack and mkiss protocols, a race condition in the floppy disk driver, use-after-free vulnerabilities in the Atheros ath9k wireless device driver and the perf subsystem, a use-after-free vulnerability in the Marvell NFC device driver, and a use-after-free vulnerability in the NFC subsystem. An attacker with local access could exploit these vulnerabilities to cause a denial of service or execute arbitrary code. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
