Another vulnerability allows a local attacker to cause a denial of service or execute arbitrary code by exploiting a use-after-free vulnerability in the netfilter subsystem. Additionally, there are several other vulnerabilities in the Linux kernel that could lead to privilege escalation, information leaks, or system crashes. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple security flaws that could lead to denial of service (DoS) attacks, privilege escalation, information exposure, and data corruption. These vulnerabilities include a use-after-free and panic flaw in the MAX-3421 USB device driver, a race condition in the ext4 subsystem, a flaw in the ASLR protection mechanism, a buffer overflow in lib/seq_buf.c, a missing guest protection page fault, a data corruption issue in virtio_console.c, a memory corruption issue in the KVM guest on PowerPC systems, an out-of-bounds read in vt_k_ioctl, a flaw in the OverlayFS subsystem, a resource exhaustion issue in the tracing module, a memory read issue in inbound SCTP packets, a memory corruption issue in the CAN BCM networking protocol, a side-channel attack in the eBPF subsystem, a privilege escalation issue in the KVM implementation, and a socket reuse issue in the DCCP protocol. These vulnerabilities could be exploited by attackers to cause DoS conditions, gain elevated privileges, expose sensitive information, and corrupt data. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple issues that could lead to denial of service (DoS) attacks or system crashes. These vulnerabilities include a flaw in the Freescale Gianfar Ethernet driver that allows attackers to cause a system crash by sending specially-crafted jumbo packets. Another vulnerability in the Xen paravirtualization backend can be exploited by an attacker in a guest VM to cause a denial of service or host domain crash. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in the Xen netback backend, USB/IP driver, netfilter subsystem, and video4linux subsystem that could result in system crashes or memory exhaustion. A local attacker could exploit these vulnerabilities to disrupt the normal operation of the system. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple security flaws, including improper access permissions, race conditions, and validation checks. These vulnerabilities could lead to denial of service conditions, exposure of sensitive information, privilege escalation, or execution of arbitrary code. One vulnerability (CVE-2021-38198) in the arch/x86/kvm/mmu/paging_tmpl.h component incorrectly computes the access permissions of a shadow page, resulting in a missing guest protection page fault. Another vulnerability (CVE-2021-40490) in the ext4 file system allows a local attacker to cause a denial of service or potentially gain administrative privileges due to a race condition when writing xattrs to an inode. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities related to the Atheros Ath9k WiFi driver, KVM hypervisor implementation, and 6pack network protocol driver. Upgrading to the specified package versions is recommended to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a use-after-free vulnerability in the NFC stack, a denial of service vulnerability in the NFC stack, a TLB flushes flaw in the hugetlb implementation, a race condition in the timer implementation, a race condition in the overlay file system implementation, an integer overflow in the eBPF implementation, and a race condition in the ISDN CAPI implementation. These vulnerabilities could lead to a threat to confidentiality, integrity, and system availability, as well as the possibility of executing arbitrary code. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Dpkg, the Debian package management system, before version 1.21.8, 1.20.10, 1.19.8, 1.18.26 is vulnerable to a directory traversal flaw. This vulnerability occurs when extracting untrusted source packages in v2 and v3 source package formats that include a debian.tar, allowing an attacker to traverse directories on the system and modify arbitrary files. subAssessmentDescription: Libgcrypt versions before 1.8.8 and 1.9.x before 1.9.3 have a vulnerability in ElGamal encryption. The lack of exponent blinding makes it susceptible to a side-channel attack against mpi_powm, and the window size is not chosen appropriately. This vulnerability affects the use of ElGamal in OpenPGP. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability to obtain sensitive information and potentially launch further attacks against the system. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A vulnerability has been discovered in nettle's RSA decryption functions, which could allow an attacker to manipulate ciphertext and cause the application to crash, resulting in a denial of service. Additionally, there is a separate vulnerability that affects Ubuntu 18.04 LTS, where certain padding oracles could be exploited to perform a variant of the Bleichenbacher attack. Red Hat's versions of the software are not affected by CVE-2021-3580. An upgrade to nettle version 3.7.2-1 or higher is recommended to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple race condition vulnerabilities, allowing attackers to cause denial of service (DoS) conditions and gain elevated privileges. These vulnerabilities include a race condition in the usbip_sockfd_store function in drivers/usb/usbip/stub_dev.c, a race condition in the netfilter subsystem when replacing tables, and a race condition in the USB/IP driver. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities in the Nouveau GPU driver, Xen netback backend, fastrpc driver, Realtek RTL8188EU Wireless device driver, and video4linux subsystem. Exploiting these vulnerabilities could result in system crashes, memory exhaustion, and information disclosure. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is affected by multiple vulnerabilities that could allow attackers to obtain sensitive information, cause denial of service (DoS) attacks, or execute arbitrary code. These vulnerabilities include an uninitialized data structure flaw in the qrtr_recvmsg function, a reference counting error in the NFC LLCP protocol implementation, a race condition in the btrfs file system implementation, a flaw in the perf subsystem, a buffer overflow in the RPA PCI Hotplug driver, a memory initialization issue in the Qualcomm IPC router implementation, a buffer overflow in the block device manager, a use-after-free vulnerability in the IEEE 1394 nosy packet sniffer driver, and an integer overflow in the ext4 file system implementation. These vulnerabilities could result in the compromise of confidentiality, integrity, and system availability. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability in systemd versions prior to 246.15, 247.8, 248.5, and 249.1 allows a local attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) by exploiting a memory allocation with an excessive size value. By sending a specially-crafted request, the attacker can crash the operating system. Red Hat's versions of the software are not affected by this vulnerability. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Upgrade to systemd versions 246.15, 247.8, 248.5, or 249.1 to mitigate the vulnerability. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple issues that could lead to denial of service (DoS) attacks and privilege escalation. These vulnerabilities include a lack of memory barrier in the netfilter subsystem, improper error handling in the Nouveau GPU driver and Xen netback backend, unrestricted kernel RPC message sending in the fastrpc driver, improper validation of ssid lengths in the Realtek RTL8188EU Wireless device driver, race conditions in the USB/IP driver and netfilter subsystem, and improper deallocation of memory in the video4linux subsystem. Exploiting these vulnerabilities could result in system crashes, memory exhaustion, and elevated privileges. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: A memory leak vulnerability was found in the TCP source port generation algorithm in the Linux Kernel's net/ipv4/tcp.c function. This flaw could allow an attacker to leak information and potentially cause a denial of service. Another vulnerability in the Linux Kernel allows a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information by exploiting a memory leak flaw in the TCP source port generation algorithm. Additionally, there are several other vulnerabilities in the Linux Kernel, including a buffer overflow in the IPsec ESP transformation code, a race condition in the perf subsystem, and a flaw in the netfilter subsystem that could lead to a denial of service. These vulnerabilities could result in privilege escalation, system crashes, or the execution of arbitrary code. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

These vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to cause a denial of service (system crash), leak internal kernel information, execute arbitrary code, or expose sensitive information. The highest threat is to system availability. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel through version 5.12.10 has multiple vulnerabilities that could allow local attackers to obtain sensitive information or execute arbitrary code. These vulnerabilities include an infoleak in struct bcm_msg_head, a double-free vulnerability in the bluetooth subsystem, a use-after-free vulnerability in the bluetooth subsystem, and a NULL pointer dereference in the NFC implementation. Exploiting these vulnerabilities could result in the exposure of sensitive information, denial of service, or arbitrary code execution. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel before version 5.13.3 has multiple vulnerabilities that could allow attackers to bypass security restrictions, defeat ASLR protection mechanisms, expose sensitive information, execute arbitrary code, cause denial of service, and corrupt memory. These vulnerabilities include a buffer overflow in lib/seq_buf.c, a use-after-free vulnerability in the KVM hypervisor implementation, a denial of service vulnerability in the tracing subsystem, a vulnerability in the overlay file system, a validation issue in the KVM implementation for PowerPC systems, a denial of service vulnerability in the MAX-3421 host USB device driver, and a vulnerability in the Xilinx 10/100 Ethernet Lite device driver. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities related to the ext4 subsystem, the ip_check_mc_rcu function in igmp.c, the access permissions computation of a shadow page, the vt_k_ioctl function in vt_ioctl.c, the TmpFS filesystem with OverlayFS, the CPU resources in the tracing module functionality, the inbound SCTP packets, the CAN BCM networking protocol, the BPF subsystem, and the reuse of a socket with an attached dccps_hc_tx_ccid as a listener. These vulnerabilities could result in data confidentiality and integrity breaches, system crashes, privilege escalation, and denial of service. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Mercurial before version 4.7.2 is vulnerable to multiple security issues. The first vulnerability involves an out-of-bounds read in the `cext/manifest.c` file during the parsing of a malformed manifest entry. This could allow a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information. The second vulnerability is related to the mishandling of symlinks in subrepositories, which could be exploited by an attacker to write arbitrary files to the target's filesystem. Additionally, Mercurial incorrectly handles certain manifest files, which could lead to a denial of service and potentially allow the execution of arbitrary code. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability affects the Expat library, specifically the xmltok_impl.c file, in versions before 2.4.5. It lacks certain validation of encoding, allowing a remote attacker to cause a denial of service condition by persuading a victim to open a specially-crafted content with malformed encoding. The vulnerability can also be exploited to execute arbitrary code. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: DjVuLibre and libopenmpt are both vulnerable to denial-of-service attacks due to out-of-bounds read vulnerabilities. In DjVuLibre, a specially crafted JB2 image file can cause an application crash by triggering an out-of-bounds read in the JB2Dict::JB2Codec::get_direct_context function. Similarly, libopenmpt is susceptible to a denial-of-service attack caused by an out-of-bounds read in the same function. Attackers can exploit these vulnerabilities by tricking users into opening malicious files, resulting in application crashes or hangs. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: DjVuLibre 3.5.27 is vulnerable to a denial-of-service (DoS) attack due to an uncontrolled recursion in the sorting functionality. Attackers can exploit this vulnerability by crafting a specially-crafted PBM image file, which is mishandled in libdjvu/GContainer.h. When a victim opens this file, it can cause the application to crash, resulting in a DoS. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel before version 5.17.6 is vulnerable to multiple denial of service (DoS) vulnerabilities. The vulnerabilities include a concurrency use-after-free flaw in the floppy driver (drivers/block/floppy.c) and race conditions in the AX.25 amateur radio protocol implementation and the KVM hypervisor implementation. These vulnerabilities could be exploited by local authenticated attackers to cause a system crash or execute arbitrary code, resulting in a DoS condition. Additionally, a use-after-free vulnerability was found in the implementation of the 6pack and mkiss protocols, which could also lead to a DoS condition. A local attacker could exploit this vulnerability to cause a system crash. Another vulnerability was discovered in the AX.25 amateur radio protocol implementation, which could be exploited by a local attacker to cause a system crash or execute arbitrary code. Furthermore, the implementation of the AX.25 amateur radio protocol in the Linux kernel contained race conditions, leading to use-after-free vulnerabilities that could be exploited by a local attacker to cause a system crash. Lastly, the KVM hypervisor implementation did not properly handle guest TLB mapping invalidation requests in some situations, allowing an attacker in a guest VM to cause a system crash in the host OS. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: Multiple vulnerabilities have been discovered in the Linux kernel. These vulnerabilities include a lack of CPU resource in the tracing module functionality, a side-channel attack due to a missed possible mispredicted branches in the BPF verifier, a denial of service in the KVM implementation for PowerPC systems, a denial of service in the Virtio console implementation, a denial of service in the NFSv4 client implementation, and a denial of service in the MAX-3421 host USB device driver. Additionally, there are vulnerabilities related to buffer overflow, use after free, race condition, ASLR protection mechanism defeat, and access permissions computation. These vulnerabilities could lead to denial of service, exposure of sensitive information, data confidentiality and integrity issues, and system availability problems. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The NetBSD kernel in version 7.1 and multiple Cisco products are vulnerable to a denial-of-service attack due to an issue with forwarding EAPOL frames from unauthenticated senders. This vulnerability allows an attacker to launch denial-of-service attacks against connected clients and potentially exploit other vulnerabilities in those clients. Additionally, the Linux kernel is affected by multiple vulnerabilities, including use-after-free, denial-of-service, and information disclosure vulnerabilities in various components such as the CAN BCM networking protocol, eBPF implementation, and WiFi implementation. These vulnerabilities could allow a local attacker to execute arbitrary code, cause system crashes, inject packets, decrypt fragments, or expose sensitive information. Red Hat's versions of the associated software are not affected by one of the vulnerabilities. The vulnerabilities can be mitigated by upgrading to specific package versions. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: The Linux kernel is vulnerable to multiple security issues. One vulnerability, identified as CVE-2022-24448, allows an attacker to leak kernel data into userspace by opening a regular file in a mounted NFS filesystem. Another vulnerability, CVE-2022-0617, is a NULL pointer dereference in the UDF file system functionality that can be triggered by a malicious UDF image, leading to a system crash. These vulnerabilities can be exploited by local attackers to cause a denial of service or expose sensitive information. Other vulnerabilities include off-path attacker data injection, use-after-free vulnerabilities, NULL pointer dereferences, and memory errors. Upgrading to the specified package versions is recommended to mitigate these vulnerabilities. [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
additionalData: {"cveDescriptionAdditionalInformation":"These vulnerabilities affect various versions of the Linux kernel and are fixed in specific package versions. The vulnerabilities include uninitialized data flaws, use-after-free vulnerabilities, NULL pointer dereferences, and memory errors. The impact of these vulnerabilities ranges from data leakage and system crashes to denial of service and privilege escalation. It is important to promptly upgrade to the recommended package versions to ensure the security and stability of affected systems. subAssessmentDescription: The vulnerability exists in nghttp2 versions before 1.41.0, Node.js, and Oracle GraalVM Enterprise Edition. In nghttp2, an attacker can exploit the vulnerability by sending overly large HTTP/2 SETTINGS frames, causing a denial of service (DoS) by consuming all available CPU resources. Node.js is also vulnerable to a DoS attack due to an error in the HTTP/2 session frame, which is limited to 32 settings by default. Oracle GraalVM Enterprise Edition is affected by an easily exploitable vulnerability that allows an unauthenticated attacker to compromise the system via HTTP, resulting in a hang or frequently repeatable crash. The CVSS 3.1 Base Score for this vulnerability is 7.5 (Availability impacts). [Generated by AI]
subAssessmentRemediation: Apply the latest patches and updates provided by the respective vendors. [Generated by AI]
additionalData: {"cveDescriptionAdditionalInformation":"The nghttp2 vulnerability has a proof of concept attack involving a malicious client constructing a SETTINGS frame with a length of 14,400 bytes (2400 individual settings entries) repeatedly. The vulnerability in Oracle GraalVM Enterprise Edition is easily exploitable and affects versions 19.3.2 and 20.1.0. The vulnerability in libnghttp2 can be fixed by updating the system to the specified package versions. Amazon Linux 2 also provides package updates to fix the nghttp2 vulnerability. subAssessmentDescription: Graphviz 2.40.1 is vulnerable to a NULL pointer dereference vulnerability in the rebuild_vlists function in lib/dotgen/conc.c in the dotgen library. This vulnerability can be exploited by remote attackers to cause a denial of service (application crash) by persuading a victim to open a specially crafted file. [Generated by AI]

subAssessmentDescription: DjVuLibre versions 3.5.28 and earlier are vulnerable to a heap buffer overflow in the DJVU::GBitmap::decode() function. This vulnerability can be exploited by a remote attacker by persuading a victim to open a specially-crafted djvu file, leading to application crashes and potentially other consequences.
